Identify red flags for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

Red Flags - When You Must Seek Medical Attention Immediately

 CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROME - CALL EMERGENCY SERVICES

 Numbness in the saddle area (around rectum/genitals)

 Loss of bladder or bowel control

 Bilateral (both legs) rapidly increasing weakness

 This is an emergency surgical situation.
 Delay can cause permanent damage. Cauda equina syndrome is rare (0.3-7 cases per 100,000 annually), but
 the consequences of delayed treatment are serious.

 Other serious signs requiring medical evaluation
 Progressive muscle weakness (increasing day by day)

 Foot drop (difficulty lifting the foot)

 Fever combined with back pain

 Unexplained weight loss

 Known cancer with new back pain

 Read more about red flags in back pain

Patient asks: "Can I exercise with SI joint pain?"

Yes, but adapted. Avoid activities that worsen pain in the acute phase. Swimming, cycling and walking are often well tolerated. Strength training for glutes and core muscles is important for long-term improvement.

Nei, til tross for at mange kaller det "senebetennelse". Moderne forskning viser at akillestendinopati primært er en degenerativ prosess med endringer i senestrukturen, ikke klassisk inflammasjon. Dette er også grunnen til at antiinflammatoriske medisiner har begrenset effekt.

Beskriv Øvelse 1: Short Foot (Kortfot) for Fottrening som virker: Øvelser for sterkere fåtter.

Øvelse 1: Short Foot (Kortfot)

 

 Short foot er den mest fundamentale Øvelsen for fothelse. Den aktiverer de intrinsiske musklene som støtter fotbuen - musklene som ofte blir «sløtt av» etter Ørevis i støttende sko.

 
 Slik gjør du Short Foot

 
 Startposisjon: Sitt på en stol med foten flat på gulvet

 Bevegelsen: Trekk forfoten mot hålen ved å «forkorte» foten

 Fokus: Løft fotbuen uten å krølle tårne

 Hold: 5 sekunder

 Gjentagelser: 10-15 repetisjoner

 Sett: 2-3 sett per fot

 
 
 Progresjon:

 
 Sittende med begge fåtter

 Stående med begge fåtter

 Stående på ett ben

 Stående på ustabilt underlag (pute, balansebrett)

 
 

 

 
 Viktig tips

 Mange prøver å «jukse» ved å krølle tårne. TØrne skal ligge flate på gulvet hele tiden - det er fotbuemusklene som skal gjøre jobben. Forestill deg at du prøver å gripe gulvet med midten av foten.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What causes Plantar Fasciopathy?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Research has identified several risk factors, ranked by how strongly they affect the chance of developing
 the condition:

 
 
 Limited ankle mobility

 23x increased risk with zero degrees dorsiflexion or less (Riddle et al., JBJS 2003)
 

 

 
 Obesity (BMI > 30)

 5-6x increased risk compared to normal weight

 

 
 Occupations with lots of standing

 4x increased risk when standing most of the workday

 

 
 Foot structure

 Both flat foot and high arch can increase load on the plantar fascia

 

 

 Sudden increase in activity - like starting to run after a long break, or increasing
 training volume too quickly - is a classic triggering factor. This type of overload can also lead to stress fractures in the foot.

Identifiser røde flagg for Morton's Nevrom.

Røde flagg - når du må oppsøke lege

 Søk lege/legevakt ved
 Nattesmerte/hvilesmerte som hovedsymptom (sjelden ved Morton's - kun 25%)

 Synlig hevelse, rødhet eller deformitet (Morton's gir ingen synlige tegn)

 Allmensymptomer som feber eller vekttap

 Bilaterale symmetriske symptomer (tyder på systemisk nevropati)

 Symptomer i 1. eller 4. mellomrom (sværtsjelden lokalisasjon for Morton's)

Forklar behandling for Stressnakke og Triggerpunkter.

Behandling

 Kiropraktisk behandling kan inkludere
 Triggerpunktterapi: Målrettet trykk for å løse opp aktive triggerpunkter

 Manuell mobilisering: Gjenopprette normal leddbevegelighet i nakke

 Bløtvevsbehandling: Massasje og myofascielle teknikker

 Dry needling: Nålebehandling av triggerpunkter

 Øvelsesopplæring: Hjemmeøvelser for styrke og avspenning

 Øvelser du kan gjøre selv

 Nakketøyning

 Bøy hodet forsiktig mot den ene skulderen. Hold 30 sekunder. Gjenta til motsatt side. Gjør 3 ganger til hver side, flere ganger daglig.

 Skulderrullinger

 Rull skuldrene langsomt bakover i store sirkler. Gjør 10 repetisjoner. Dette løsner opp spenninger i øvre trapezius.

 Hakefremtrekk (chin tucks)

 Trekk haken rett bakover som om du lager "dobbelthake". Hold 5 sekunder. Gjenta 10 ganger. Korrigerer fremoverlent hodestilling.

 Pusteøvelser

 Dyp diafragmapusting aktiverer det parasympatiske nervesystemet og reduserer muskelspenning. Pust inn i 4 sekunder, hold 4 sekunder, pust ut i 6 sekunder. Gjenta i 5 minutter.

 Stressmestring

 For varig bedring må ofte underliggende stress adresseres
 Regelmessig fysisk aktivitet

 Tilstrekkelig søvn (7-9 timer)

 Avspenningsteknikker (meditasjon, yoga)

 Sosial støtte og balanse mellom arbeid og fritid

 Ved behov: Profesjonell hjelp for stressmestring

 Prognose

 De fleste opplever god bedring med behandling. Utfordringen ligger ofte i å forebygge tilbakefall, som krever vedvarende fokus på ergonomi, øvelser og stressmestring.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Pes Anserine Bursitis.

What is Pes Anserine Bursitis?: The pes anserine bursa lies about 5 cm below the knee joint on the inside of the tibia. It acts as a
 cushion between the three tendons (sartorius, gracilis, semitendinosus) and the bone.

Symptoms: The pain from pes anserine bursitis is below the joint line, while meniscus pain is
 typically at the joint line. Bursitis also doesn't give locking or clicking like a meniscus injury can.

Treatment: Treatment is almost always conservative with good results
FAQ: See all knee pain FAQs ?

Patient asks: "Is chiropractic treatment safe with a herniation?"

For most people with uncomplicated herniation, chiropractic treatment is safe when
 performed by a licensed chiropractor. Treatment is adapted to the condition and is not appropriate for
 cauda equina syndrome, progressive neurological deficit, or
 sequestered herniation with severe symptoms.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for SLAP-lesjon: Alt du trenger å vite.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Er operasjon nødvendig for SLAP-lesjon?

 Ofte ikke. Den norske SLAP-studien (BMJ 2017) viste at kirurgi ikke var bedre enn sham-operasjon. 78% av pasienter med type II SLAP-lesjon returnerer til idrett med konservativ behandling alene.

 

 
 Hvordan diagnostiseres SLAP-lesjon?

 Diagnosen er utfordrende. Kliniske tester har moderat noyaktighet. MR artrografi er gullstandard, men selv denne har begrensninger. Mange SLAP-lesjoner er tilfeldige funn uten å forårsake symptomer.

 

 
 Kan jeg fortsette å kaste med SLAP-lesjon?

 Med riktig rehabilitering kan mange returnere til kast. Fokus på rotatormansjett-styrke, scapula-kontroll og gradvis opptrapping er nåkkel. Noen kan trenge å modifisere teknikk eller redusere intensitet.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen på SLAP-lesjon og biceps tendinopati?

 SLAP-lesjon påvirker festet der bicepssenen fester seg til labrum (leddlepen), mens biceps tendinopati påvirker selve senen. De kan gi lignende symptomer og opptre samtidig, men SLAP er mer forbundet med overheadidrett og instabilitetssymptomer.

 

 
 Hvor lang tid tar rehabilitering?

 Konservativ rehabilitering tar typisk 3-6 måneder. Ved kirurgi er rehabiliteringen lengre (4-6 måneder for retur til idrett). Fullstendig tilbakegang til kasteidrett kan ta 9-12 måneder etter operasjon.

 

 
 Betyr MR-funn at jeg har et problem?

 Ikke nødvendigvis. Mange har labrum-forandringer på MR uten symptomer - særlig over 40 Ør. Et MR-funn må alltid sees i sammenheng ...

Pasient spør: "Kan stramme muskler virkelig gi hodepine?"
Ja. Triggerpunkter i nakke- og ansiktsmuskulatur gir dokumentert referert smerte til hodet. I studier gjenkjenner 45% av hodepinepasienter smerten fra et triggerpunkt som sin vanlige hodepine.
You are a quick clinical text assistant. Generate concise clinical summaries for chiropractic documentation.
Provide a structured clinical overview of Jaw Exercises and Home Treatment for TMD.

Why Do Jaw Exercises Help?: Jaw exercises work by improving blood flow in the masticatory muscles, reducing muscle tension and restoring normal movement in the jaw joint.

Coordination Exercises - Strongest Evidence: Coordination exercises show the most suitable effect according to systematic review (Shimada et al., 2023). These exercises train the jaw to move controlled and symmetrically.

The Rocabado 6x6 Program: This is the most documented exercise protocol for TMD. The principle is simple: 6 exercises, 6 repetitions, 6 times daily.

Stretching Exercises: Place thumb on lower front teeth and index finger on upper ones. Open mouth gently with finger help, hold for 10-30 seconds. Repeat 3-5 times.

Heat and Cold - Proper Use: A survey from the TMJ Association shows that 74% of patients experience relief with thermal therapy.

Self-Massage of the Masticatory Muscles: The masseter muscle (the large chewing muscle under the cheek) is often tight and tender in TMD. Simple self-massage can help.

Diet and Stress Management: A study from 2021 showed that over 77% of TMD patients change their diet due to symptoms. Soft diet reduces stress on the jaw joint.

How Long Does It Take for Exercises to Work?: Don't expect miracles overnight. Early response may be noticed after 1-2 weeks, but meaningful improvement typically requires 6-8 weeks of consistent effort (PMC, 2023).

When Do You Need Professional Help?: Self-treatment is effective for most, but not all. Seek professional evaluation if

Beskriv Slitasje (degenerative forandringer) i kontekst av Kne- og leggsmerter – Komplett guide.

Slitasje (degenerative forandringer)

 Med alderen får mange naturlige aldersforandringer i kne og menisker. De fleste degenerative meniskfunn på MR gir ingen symptomer. Kneartrose utvikler seg gradvis over Ør og gir Økende smerter, stivhet og redusert bevegelighet.

Patient asks: "Do orthotics work for overpronation?"

Evidence is weak. Large studies (Nielsen 2013) showed no difference in injury rates when runners got shoes matched to foot type versus neutral shoes. "Overpronation" as a diagnosis lacks scientific basis.

Beskriv Hvorfor lever myten videre? for Overpronasjon: Myte eller medisinsk faktum?.

Hvorfor lever myten videre?

 

 Til tross for manglende vitenskapelig støtte fortsetter overpronasjon-konseptet å dominere. Hvorfor?

 
 
 $3.7-4.8
 milliarder - globalt ortosemarked
 

 

 Økonomiske insentiver

 Ortoseindustrien er enorm. Produsenter, forhandlere og behandlere har betydelige Økonomiske interesser i å opprettholde forestillingen om at mange mennesker trenger fotkorrigering.

 Tradisjon og utdanning

 Overpronasjon-teorien har vårt undervist i helseutdanninger i Ørtier. Mange behandlere lærte dette som etablert vitenskap og har ikke oppdatert seg på nyere forskning.

 Visuell logikk

 Det ser feil ut når foten ruller innover. Vi er programmert til å tenke at det som ser unormalt ut, må våre skadelig. Men kroppen er mer robust og tilpasningsdyktig enn vi ofte tror.

 Placebo-effekt

 Mange opplever bedring med ortoser. Men studier viser at denne effekten ofte er placebo - narresaler gir samme effekt som dyre spesialtilpassede ortoser.

Describe Checklist: Are Orthotics Right for You? for When Orthotics Actually Help.

Checklist: Are Orthotics Right for You?

 

 
 Orthotics may be right if:

 
 You have diabetic neuropathy with foot ulcer risk

 You have rheumatoid arthritis with foot joint involvement

 You have symptomatic pes cavus (painful high arch)

 You are rehabilitating after foot surgery

 You have an acute injury that needs temporary offloading

 

 Orthotics are probably NOT right if:

 
 You have been diagnosed with "overpronation" without other symptoms

 You have flexible flat feet without pain

 You have nonspecific heel pain/plantar fasciitis

 You have knee, hip or back pain

 You have used orthotics for years without improvement

 You were recommended orthotics after a quick assessment in a shoe store

 
 

 If you're unsure, you should get a thorough evaluation from a professional who can provide an objective recommendation based on your individual situation - not based on what they sell.

Describe What is Nociplastic Pain? for Nociplastic Pain: When the Nervous System Becomes Oversensitive.

What is Nociplastic Pain?

 

 In 2017, the International Association for the Study of Pain (IASP) introduced the term nociplastic pain as a third pain category alongside the two traditional ones:

 The Three Types of Pain

 
 
 
 Type
 Cause
 Examples
 
 
 
 
 Nociceptive
 Tissue damage activates pain receptors
 Sprain, fracture, osteoarthritis
 
 
 Neuropathic
 Damage to the nervous system itself
 Sciatica, carpal tunnel, diabetic neuropathy
 
 
 Nociplastic
 Altered pain processing in the nervous system
 Fibromyalgia, chronic low back pain, IBS
 
 
 

 In nociplastic pain, the nervous system has become "turned up" - it sends and amplifies pain signals even without corresponding input from the tissues. This is also called central sensitization.

 
 An Analogy: The Volume Knob

 Think of the pain system as an amplifier. Normally, the volume is set at an appropriate level - you feel pain when something is wrong, and the pain subsides when the injury heals. With central sensitization, someone has turned the volume up to 10 and broken off the knob. Now even weak signals are amplified into intense pain.

 

 How Common is This?

 
 
 20-30%
 of chronic pain patients
 

 
 Women
 affected more often than men
 

 
 Often
 overlapping conditions

Røde flagg - Oppsøk lege umiddelbart

 Plutselig kald, blek eller bla arm

 Kraftig hevelse i armen som utvikler seg raskt

Forklar behandling for Morton's Nevrom.

Behandling

 Sterk evidens for manuell behandling

 Manuell behandling representerer en av kun to intervensjoner med sterk evidens for Morton's nevrom, ifølge Matthews' systematiske oversikt fra 2019.

 79% 
 oppnadde full smertefrihet (VAS 0) innen 6 behandlinger

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 1

 Mobilisering av mellomfot og taledd

 Gjenoppretter normal leddbevegelse og reduserer kompresjon

 2

 Bløtvevsbehandling av forfoten

 Lindrer muskelspanning og bedrer sirkulasjon

 3

 Veiledning om riktig fottoy

 Bred taboks, lav hæl (under 3 cm), mykt materiale

 4

 Metatarsalputer

 Plasseres bak taballene for å spre mellomfotsbeina og avlaste nerven

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Fottoyendringer - viktigst: Sko med bred taboks som ikke klemmer tårne sammen. Fjern alle sko med smal front

 Metatarsalputer: Plasseres rett bak taballene (retrocapital posisjon)

 Unngå høye heler: Maks 3 cm hælhøyde

 Realistiske forventninger

 Ren konservativ behandling (fottoy + ortoser uten injeksjoner) lykkes hos ca. 30-50% . Ved symptomvarighet over 4,5 måneder og nevrom >5-6 mm er ortoser og fottoyendringer alene sjelden tilstrekkelig.

 Injeksjonsbehandling

 Ultralydveiledet kortisoninjeksjon kan vurderes dersom konservativ behandling ikke gir tilstrekkelig effekt etter 8-12 uker. Langtidseffekten er imidlertid begrenset - ved 5-Ørs oppfølg var injeksjonene fortsatt effektive hos kun 36%.

 Kirurgi

 Vurderes etter minst 6-9 måneder med mislykket konservativ behandling. Nevrektomi gir 74% full smertefrihet . 72% får nummenhet i forsynte tar - dette er forventet og påvirker generelt ikke tilfredsheten.

Patient asks: "Why is my headache worse at work?"

Prolonged sitting, screen work and poor ergonomics are common triggers for both cervicogenic and tension-type headaches. The neck muscles are strained by sustained positions. A chiropractor can provide specific ergonomic advice and exercises for office workers.
You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain treatment — exercise vs. surgery for Rotator Cuff — Complete Guide to the Rotator Cuff.

Treatment — exercise vs. surgery

 Research on rotator cuff treatment has changed dramatically over the last 10-15 years. Norway has been at the forefront of this development. 

 Exercise as first-line treatment

 For degenerative (atraumatic) rotator cuff injuries — which make up the vast majority — structured exercise is the first-line treatment. Several high-quality studies support this
 Norwegian research: Moosmayer et al.

 Stefan Moosmayer and colleagues at Oslo and Lovisenberg conducted a randomised controlled trial comparing exercise with surgery for small and medium-sized rotator cuff tears. Results after 1 year showed no significant difference between the groups (Kukkonen et al., 2015, Bone Joint J).

 Even more impressively: at 10-year follow-up (Moosmayer et al., 2019) there was still no clinically meaningful difference. The exercise group did just as well as the surgery group in the long term.

 The OPTIROT study (ongoing)

 OPTIROT is a large Norwegian randomised study comparing exercise with surgery for small and medium-sized tears. The study is led from Oslo and Lovisenberg and is one of the most important ongoing studies in the field internationally.

 Re-tear after surgery: 20-40%

 An important point that is often under-communicated: 20-40% of surgically repaired rotator cuff tears re-tear (Carr et al., 2015, Lancet). For large and massive tears, the re-tear rate is even higher. Interestingly, many patients have good function despite re-tear — which raises the question of whether it is the rehabilitation itself, rather than the tendon healing, that produces results.

Describe causes and risk factors for AC Joint Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Primary Causes

 Age-Related Wear

 Most Common 

 Normal degeneration over time. The AC joint is one of the first joints in the body to show
 age-related changes, often from the 20-30 age range.

 Overload and Repetitive Activity

 Occupations or sports with lots of overhead work or heavy lifting put extra stress on the joint.
 Common in
 Powerlifters and crossfitters

 Carpenters and painters

 Overhead athletes (volleyball, handball, tennis)

 Previous Injury

 An AC joint separation or collarbone fracture increases the risk of later osteoarthritis in the
 joint.

 Weightlifter's Shoulder (Distal Clavicular Osteolysis)

 Special Condition in Strength Athletes

 Weightlifter's shoulder is a condition where the end of the collarbone breaks down due to repetitive
 microtrauma. Common in those who train heavy bench press, shoulder press and dips.

 Pain on top of the shoulder

 Worsens with heavy lifting

 X-ray shows dissolution of the outer end of the collarbone

 93% improve with activity modification 

 Risk Factors

 Age over 40 years

 Heavy physical work or strength training

 Previous AC joint injury

 Overhead sports

 Previous collarbone or shoulder fracture

Describe Rib Fracture (costa fracture) in the context of Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture.

Rib Fracture (costa fracture)

 A rib fracture occurs when one or more ribs get a crack or a complete break in the bone structure. This
 typically happens after trauma - a fall, a blow to the chest, or a car accident.

 Rib fractures are relatively common injuries. Approximately 10% of all trauma patients admitted to
 hospital have one or more rib fractures (StatPearls, 2024). In older people with osteoporosis, fractures
 can occur with much less force - sometimes just from severe coughing.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Thoracic Disc Herniation.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How common is thoracic disc herniation?

 Very rare. Only 0.25-0.75% of all symptomatic disc herniations occur in the
 thoracic spine. In comparison, the lumbar spine accounts for about 90% and the cervical spine for about
 8%.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor treat thoracic disc herniation?

 The chiropractor's main role is to identify the condition and assess severity. For
 confirmed herniation without neurological deficits, gentle treatment of surrounding structures may be
 considered. With myelopathic signs, the patient is referred onward.

 

 
 Why does it take so long to get a diagnosis?

 Symptoms can resemble heart disease, lung conditions, or gastrointestinal
 problems. Average delay is 14-16 months from symptom onset to correct diagnosis.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Most people don't need surgery. About 73-80% recover with conservative treatment.
 Surgery is indicated for progressive neurological symptoms or lack of improvement after 6-12 weeks.
 

 

 
 Are MRI findings always significant?

 No. 37% of healthy people without symptoms have disc bulges in the thoracic spine
 on MRI. Imaging findings must always be interpreted together with symptoms and clinical findings.

 

 
 Can the condition resolve on its own?

 Symptoms can improve, but spontaneous regression of the actual herniation is very
 rarely documented for thoracic cases - unlike lumbar herniations.

 

 
 Which sports increase the risk?

Describe causes and risk factors for Trigger Points in the Neck.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Trigger points develop near muscle fibers that become overloaded or damaged. The most common causes,
 ranked by frequency
 Static Loading and Poor Ergonomics (Most Common)

 Prolonged desk work, screen use with forward head position, and repetitive work are by far the most
 common causes. Office workers and manual laborers have similar trigger point distribution, with an
 average of 6 active and 10-11 latent trigger points (Fernandez-De-Las-Penas 2012).

 Muscular Overload

 Repetitive movements, heavy lifting, or sudden increased training load.

 Stress and Tension

 Psychological stress often leads to chronic muscle tension, especially in the neck and shoulders.

 Other Factors

 Sleep problems and fatigue: Poor sleep reduces the muscles' ability to recover

 Vitamin D deficiency: About one-third of MPS patients have low vitamin D levels
 (StatPearls 2025)

 Trauma: Whiplash and other injuries. Among whiplash patients, 55-65% have trigger
 points in levator scapulae

 Who is affected?

 MPS occurs most often in the 27-50 age group. Women are affected more often than men - 65% versus 37%
 among middle-aged adults (Steen, Muscle & Nerve 2025).

Hva er triggerpunkter?

 

 Triggerpunkter er hypersensitive områder i muskelfibre - ofte beskrevet som "knuter" eller "strammer". Når du trykker på et triggerpunkt, gir det karakteristisk smerte, og ofte også referred pain - smerte som stråler ut til andre områder.

 Aktive triggerpunkter Gir symptomer

 Gir spontan smerte og referred pain. Kan forstyrre søvn og påvirke daglig funksjon.

 

 
 Latente triggerpunkter

 Omme bare ved trykk. Kan begrense bevegelighet og svekke muskelen, men gir ikke spontan smerte.

Describe Who is Affected? for Flat Back (Hypokyphosis).

Who is Affected?

 

 Hypokyphosis and Straight Back Syndrome have a clear age pattern. A review of 114 SBS patients showed
 that 95% were under 40 years, and 60% were between 20 and 40 years (Jiang & Li, referenced in Kong et al.,
 World Journal of Cardiology, 2023). The condition appears to become rarer with age.

 
 Groups with increased prevalence

 
 Gymnasts and ballet dancers more often develop flat back, probably due to repeated
 extension movements. A study of 33 ballet dancers found hypokyphosis in 9.1% (MDPI, 2021).

 Patients with idiopathic scoliosis often have concurrent reduced kyphosis as part
 of the three-dimensional spinal deformity.

 After spinal surgery: Historically, Harrington rods were known to flatten the back.
 Modern techniques provide better control, but studies still show that 31% of scoliosis surgery
 patients have reduced kyphosis at follow-up (PMC, 2013).

Describe How Text Neck Affects the Jaw for Text Neck and Jaw Pain: How Mobile Use Affects the Jaw.

How Text Neck Affects the Jaw

 

 The connection between forward head posture and jaw problems is well documented:

 
 1. Biomechanical Change

 When the head moves forward:

 
 The lower jaw is pulled backward and down by gravity

 The jaw muscles must work to keep the mouth closed

 The jaw joint is loaded asymmetrically

 The posterior part of the joint is compressed

 
 

 
 2. Muscular Compensation

 
 Masseter and temporalis are activated unnecessarily

 Constant low-level tension leads to fatigue

 Increased risk of trigger points

 Tension headaches in the temples

 
 

 
 3. Nerve Connections

 
 The trigeminocervical complex connects neck and jaw

 Tight neck muscles can cause referred pain to the jaw

 Suboccipital tension affects jaw muscles reflexively

 
 

 
 Research Confirms the Connection

 Studies show that 70-90% of TMD patients have concurrent neck problems, and that treatment of the neck often improves jaw symptoms - even without direct jaw treatment.

Describe Motion-Triggered MdDS (Most Common) in the context of Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS).

Motion-Triggered MdDS (Most Common)

 
 Cruise or boat travel - by far the most common trigger

 Air travel

 Long car journey or train ride

 Elevator ride or walking on a pier

 
 

 Temporary "mal de debarquement" after sea travel occurs in 73-86% of people, even among experienced sailors. Longer trips and rough seas can increase the risk, but the duration of exposure does not seem to determine severity.

 
 Spontaneous/Non-Motion-Triggered MdDS (Rarer)

 
 Hormonal changes - studies show that ~44% had symptom onset during perimenopause or menopause

 Psychological stress or major life events

 Surgical procedures

 Head injury

 Without identifiable cause

 
 

 Who Is Affected?

 MdDS has a clear demographic profile:

 
 Women make up 80-90% of cases

 Average onset age: 43-50 years

 Sex ratio: Women:men approximately 9:1

 Migraine: People with migraine have increased risk of developing MdDS. These patients may also experience vestibular migraine

 
 

 
 
 3
 Symptoms

 

 Main Symptoms

 The characteristic symptom is a persistent oscillating dizziness - a sensation of:

 
 Rocking

 Swaying motion

 Bobbing (up-down movement)

 
 Symptoms are present continuously or most of the day. They are not accompanied by the spinning sensation (vertigo) seen in BPPV (crystal disease).

 Associated Symptoms

 Many with MdDS develop additional symptoms:

 
 Spatial disorientation

 Fatigue

 Intolerance to visual motion (busy environments, escalators)

 Headache - often migraine-like

 Anxiety and depression

 Cognitive difficulties ("brain fog")

 Concentration problems

 Sleep difficulties

 Neck and back pain

 

 
 The Paradox: Better in Motion

 An important characteristic of MdDS is that symptoms often improve when in passive motion - such as driving a car or sitting on a train. But symptoms return - and may temporarily worsen - when the motion stops.

 This distinguishes MdDS from PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness), where symptoms typically worsen with motion.

Differential diagnoses for You Don't Have to Live With Dizziness Anymore?

BPPV - Vertigo

 BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) is the most common cause of rotational dizziness and accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness cases. The condition occurs when small calcium particles dislodge in the inner ear and end up in the semicircular canals.

 Typical characteristics: Brief, intense dizziness episodes (seconds to one minute) triggered by head movements - such as turning in bed, bending down, or looking up.

 Treatment response: Studies show 80-90% improvement with repositioning maneuvers like Epley. Many experience improvement after one treatment, while others need 2-3 treatments. Success rate after repeated treatments is over 90-95%.

Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related)

 Studies show that up to 40% of patients with neck pain also experience dizziness. The upper cervical vertebrae (C1-C3) contain a high concentration of position sense receptors that send information to the brain about head position. When these signals are disturbed, the result can be unsteadiness and dizziness.

 Typical characteristics: Persistent unsteadiness that worsens with neck movements, often combined with neck pain and headache.

 Treatment response: A systematic review from 2011 concluded that there is moderate evidence for manual treatment of cervicogenic dizziness. Treatment is often combined with specific exercises.

Vestibular Neuritis

 An inflammation of the balance nerve, often after a viral infection. Causes sudden, intense dizziness that lasts for days to weeks.

 Treatment response: Vestibular rehabilitation shows significant effect. A Cochrane review found statistically significant improvement compared to no treatment.

Other Causes

 Vestibular migraine, Meniere's disease, medication side effects, and orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure drop when standing) are among other common causes. Sometimes multiple conditions overlap.

Treatment

 Phase 1: Pain management (weeks 1-2)

 Too rapid return to full activity

 Only passive treatment - exercise is necessary

 Ignoring pain signals - "train through the pain"

How is Chronic Dizziness and PPPD diagnosed?

The Five Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society, 2017)

 

 
 1. Duration

 Dizziness, unsteadiness or non-rotational vertigo present most days for at least three months

 

 
 2. Aggravating Factors

 Symptoms worsen with upright posture, active or passive movement, and visually complex or moving stimuli

 

 
 3. Triggering Event

 The condition started after an acute vestibular disorder, other medical illness, or psychological stress

 

 
 4. Symptom Impact

 Symptoms cause significant distress or functional impairment

 

 
 5. No Better Explanation

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another disease

Hvorfor gjør det vondt å kjøre bil?: Tre mekanismer samvirker for å gjøre bilkjøring spesielt belastende for korsryggen
Slik stiller du inn bilsetet riktig: God seteinnstilling koster ingenting og kan gjøre stor forskjell. Her er de viktigste justeringene
Korsryggstøtte - hva fungerer?: Mange moderne biler har innebygd justerbar lendestøtte. Bruk den. Still den slik at du kjenner en mild støtte i korsryggsvingen uten at det presser deg fremover.

Pauserutiner - nøkkelrådet: Stopp hvert 90-120 minutter. Statens vegvesen anbefaler dette for trafikksikkerhet, men det er minst like viktig for ryggen. Ta minimum 10-15 minutters pause med bevegelse.

Etter lang kjøring - ta det rolig: Her gjør mange en klassisk feil: de hopper ut av bilen og løfter tunge kofferter rett fra bagasjerommet. Etter timer med statisk belastning er mellomvirvelskivene mer sårbare. Risikoen for akutt ryggsmerte øker.

Spesielle hensyn: Bruk ekstra korsryggstøtte. Ta hyppigere pauser enn vanlig. Plasser sikkerhetsbeltet under magen (aldri over). Les mer om graviditet og ryggsmerter .

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How do I know if my rib is broken or just dislocated?

 The most important clue is the trauma history. With a fracture, you remember
 exactly what happened - a fall, a blow, an accident. With dislocation, the history is often more vague.
 The intensity is also different - fractures typically cause more intense pain that makes it difficult to
 take deep breaths. A clinical examination can usually distinguish between the conditions.

 

 
 Do I need an X-ray to know if my rib is broken?

 Not necessarily. Norwegian guidelines state that rib fractures are primarily a
 clinical diagnosis. X-rays also have low accuracy (about 50%) and rarely change treatment for
 uncomplicated fractures. Imaging becomes important when complications are suspected or with serious
 trauma.

 

 
 Can I exercise with rib dislocation?

 Yes, but adapt the activity. Avoid exercises that provoke pain, especially heavy
 rotational movements. Light activity like walking is often perfectly fine. After treatment, you can
 gradually resume normal training.

 

 
 How long am I on sick leave with rib fractures?

 It depends on the nature of the work. For physically demanding work, 4-6 weeks may
 be necessary. For sedentary work, many can return earlier, but with adjustments. As a chiropractor, I
 can write sick leave for up to 12 weeks.

 

 
 Why does it hurt so much to breathe?

 The nerves that run along the ribs (intercostal nerves) become irritated with both
 fractures a...

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjore?

 Grundig undersokelse: Kliniske tester for a kartlegge hvilke strukturer som er affisert og alvorlighetsgrad

 Individuelt treningsprogram: Tilpasset din skadetype, smerteniva og funksjonskrav

 Rehabiliteringsveiledning: Gradvis progresjon tilbake til normale aktiviteter

 Brystrygg og nakke — den glemte sammenhengen

 Mange med rotator cuff-plager har stivhet i brystrygg og/eller nakke som bidrar til overbelastning av skulderen. Nar brystryggen er stiv, ma skulderen kompensere med mer bevegelse. Behandling av brystrygg og nakke kan derfor vare en viktig del av rehabiliteringen.

 Hva kan du gjore selv?

 Pendelovelser: Len deg fremover, la armen henge og sving forsiktig i sirkler. 2-3 ganger daglig

 Isometrisk utadrotasjon: Sta med albuen i 90 grader mot en dorkarm. Press utover uten bevegelse. Hold 10 sek, 10 gjentagelser

 Scapula-klem: Trekk skulderbladene bakover og ned. Hold 5 sek, 10 gjentagelser, 3 ganger daglig

 Is etter aktivitet: 15-20 min ved smerteforverring

 Sovnstilling: Soving pa den friske siden med en pute under den vonde armen kan lindre nattesmerter

Symptomer

 

 De typiske symptomene ved occipital nevralgi er karakteristiske og skiller seg fra andre hodepinetyper:

 Stikkende, skytende eller brennende smerte

 Ofte beskrevet som "elektriske støt"

 Starter ved nakke-/bakhodegrensen og stråler oppover mot bakhodet

 Kan nå helt frem til pannen eller bak Øyet

 Anfallsmønster

 
 Anfall av intens smerte som varer sekunder til minutter

 Kan ha underliggende verkende smerte mellom anfallene

 Nummenhet eller prikking i hodebunnen

 Lysfålsomhet (mindre vanlig enn ved migrene)

Describe Myth 1: "Dizziness and vertigo are the same thing" in the context of Dizziness: Myths Debunked and Real Help Available.

Myth 1: "Dizziness and vertigo are the same thing"

 Fact: Dizziness is a broad term that encompasses several different experiences: feeling unstable, lightheaded, about to faint, or that the world is spinning around. Vertigo is a specific subtype where you experience a sensation of rotation.

 Distinguishing between these is important for finding the right cause and treatment. Vertigo often points to the vestibular system, while other types of dizziness can be caused by anything from blood pressure drops to neck problems or anxiety.

Describe causes and risk factors for Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy.

Causes and Risk Factors

 The condition most often develops gradually as a result of overload and degeneration.

 Overweight

 Increased load on the tendon, especially with BMI over 25

 Female gender

 4 times more common in women, possible hormonal factor

 Age over 40

 The tendon naturally degenerates with age

 Diabetes

 Affects blood supply and tendon quality

 Hypertension

 Associated with reduced blood supply to the tendon

 Previous injury

 Ankle injuries and ankle instability can predispose to PTTD

 Athletes who engage in running, basketball or tennis can also develop the condition due
 to repeated loading. Load injuries can also affect the Achilles
 tendon and lead to stress fractures in the foot .

What causes SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes and risk factors

 

 SLAP lesions can occur in several ways:

 Acute injury

 
 Fall on outstretched arm: Compression forces push the upper arm bone up against the
 labrum

 Direct trauma: Blow to the shoulder

 Sudden pull: Heavy lifting or jerking of the arm

 

 Overload (most common)

 
 
 Repetitive overhead activity

 Main cause
 

 Throwing movements and overhead sports expose the biceps attachment to repeated pulling forces. Over
 time, this can lead to SLAP lesion. Common in:

 
 Handball players (see thrower's shoulder)

 Volleyball players

 Baseball pitchers

 Swimmers

 Tennis players

 
 

 Risk factors

 
 Overhead sports, especially throwing sports

 Age 20-40 years for traumatic lesions

 Age over 40 for degenerative changes (type I)

 Glenohumeral internal rotation deficit (GIRD)

 Weak scapula control

 Previous shoulder instability

 

 
 Important perspective

 Many have SLAP lesions on MRI without symptoms. A study found that up to 55% of asymptomatic
 shoulders in people over 45 years had labrum changes. This means an MRI finding does not necessarily
 explain your pain.

 unngå

 Når Øvelser ikke er prøvd

Behandling

 

 Kiropraktisk behandling

 SI-leddsproblemer er en av de vanligste tilstandene kiropraktorer behandler, og resultatene er ofte gode.

 
 Leddmanipulasjon - spesifikk justering av SI-leddet for å gjenopprette normal funksjon

 Mobilisering - mykere teknikker for de som foretrekker det

 Bektvevsbehandling - av stram muskulatur rundt bekken

 Taping - kan gi støtte i akuttfasen

 

 StabiliseringsØvelser

 Core-stabilitet - transversus abdominis, multifidus

 Hoftemuskulatur - gluteus medius og maximus

 Balanse og koordinasjon

 unngå asymmetrisk belastning - ikke stå på ett ben lenge

 Pute mellom knarne ved sideligging

 Beveg deg regelmessig - unngå langvarig sitting

 Varme kan lindre stivhet

Describe symptoms and causes for Jaw Joint Problems.

Symptoms and Causes

 How does it feel?

 Jaw pain: Deep, aching pain in front of the ear or along the jawline. Worse with
 chewing, yawning or long talking.

 Headache: Affects over half with TMD. Often as pressure behind the eye or a band
 around the temple.

 Ear symptoms: Ear pain, tinnitus or "blocked ear" – without the ear doctor finding
 anything.

 Limited opening: Normal is 40-55 mm (about three fingers vertically).

 Neck pain: Up to 70% of TMD patients have concurrent neck problems.

 Morning stiffness: Common if you clench your teeth at night.

 What causes it?

 Stress and muscle tension

 Go to full article on stress and jaw pain
 ? 

 Most common factor. Under stress, many clench their teeth unconsciously – day and night.

 Poor posture

 Go to full article on text neck and jaw
 ? 

 Forward-leaning head during screen work pulls the jaw backwards and compresses the joint. 76%
 of TMD patients have forward head posture (PMC 2021).

 Teeth grinding (bruxism)

 Go to full article on teeth
 grinding ? 

 8-10% have night-time bruxism (Zielinski 2024). But the connection with TMD pain is more complicated
 than previously thought.

 Neck problems

 Go to full article on neck-jaw
 connection ? 

 Nerve connections between jaw and upper neck (trigeminocervical nucleus) mean that problems in one
 place can cause symptoms in the other.

Forklar pusteøvelser som faktisk virker for Pust, Stress og Rygg.

Pusteøvelser som faktisk virker

 Hva sier forskningen?

 En metaanalyse fra 2023 (Fincham et al., Scientific Reports) analyserte 12 randomiserte studier med 785 deltakere. Konklusjon: Pusteøvelser gå signifikant stressreduksjon med en effektstørrelse på Hedges' g = -0,35 sammenlignet med kontrollgrupper.

 Stanford-studien (Yilmaz Balban et al., 2023) sammenlignet fire teknikker hos 108 deltakere over 28 dager. Overraskelsen: Syklisk sukking (forlenget utpust) var mer effektivt enn mindfulness-meditasjon for å forbedre humår og redusere stress.

 Praktiske teknikker

 Diafragmatisk pust

 Legg en hånd på magen og en på brystet. Pust inn gjennom nesen slik at magen hever seg mens brystet holder seg relativt rolig. Pust ut sakte gjennom munnen.

 Frekvens: 4-6 pust per minutt

 Varighet: Minimum 5 minutter

 Hyppighet: Daglig, gjerne flere korte økter

 Syklisk sukking (fra Stanford-studien)

 Pust inn gjennom nesen til lungene føles fulle

 Ta enda et lite innpust for å fylle helt opp

 Pust ut sakte og fullstendig gjennom munnen

 Gjenta i 5 minutter

 4-4-4-4 (boks-pusting)

 Pust inn i 4 sekunder, hold i 4 sekunder, pust ut i 4 sekunder, hold i 4 sekunder. Gjenta.

Explain prevention – stay injury-free on the course for Golf Injuries and Chiropractic Care.

Prevention – stay injury-free on the course

 Most golf injuries are preventable. Here are the three most important measures based on research.

 10-minute warm-up protocol

 An effective warm-up before golf should include dynamic stretching and a gradual increase in swing speed. Here is a simple routine
 Before you swing: 10 minutes

 Minutes 1-3: Brisk walking or light jogging to raise body temperature

 Minutes 3-5: Dynamic stretching - trunk rotations, arm circles, hip flexors, hamstrings. Hold 2 seconds per position, 10 repetitions

 Minutes 5-7: Swing with two irons together (for resistance) at a slow tempo. 10-15 swings with gradual increase

 Minutes 7-10: Start with a wedge/short iron at the range. Build up to full speed over 10-15 balls

 Strength and mobility: 3 times per week

 A preventive training program for golfers should focus on three main areas
 Training program for golfers

 Focus Area 
 Exercises 
 Sets/Reps 

 Core musculature 
 Pallof press, dead bug, plank with rotation, side plank 
 3 x 10-12 

 Thoracic mobility 
 Open book, cat-cow, thread the needle, foam roller extension 
 2 x 10 

 Hip mobility 
 90/90 stretch, hip CARs, pigeon stretch, deep squat hold 
 2 x 10 

 Gluteal strength 
 Romanian deadlift, hip thrust, lateral band walk 
 3 x 10-12 

 Scapular stability 
 Rows, face pulls, external rotation with band 
 3 x 12-15 

 Technique improvement

 Even small adjustments in technique can have a major impact on loading
 Avoid reverse spine angle: Keep a slightly bent lead knee during the backswing and allow the upper body to rotate over the trail hip, not away from it.

 Hip-initiated downswing: Start the downswing with a lateral hip shift followed by rotation. This creates a natural sequence that offloads the lower back.

 Balanced finish: End the swing in a stable position with weight over the lead foot. If you lose your balance, the swing is too hard for your current mobility level.

Vurder røde flagg: 42 år kvinne med kronisk nakkestivhet og spenningshodepine, kommer regelmessig til behandling. I dag nevner hun i forbifarten at hun har hatt en ny type hodepine siste 3 dager — intens, bak venstre øre, annerledes enn vanlig. Ellers føler hun seg fin.

- Pasienten bagatelliserer ("ellers fin") men disseksjon kan presentere uten dramatiske symptomer initialt
- Selv uten nevrologiske utfall NÅ, kan disseksjon gi slag timer-dager senere

OBS: Fravær av nevrologiske utfall utelukker IKKE disseksjon.

Funn som krever utredning:
- Ny hodepine-type (endret mønster)
- Retroaurikulær lokalisasjon
- Akutt debut (3 dager)

HANDLING: Ikke utfør cervikal behandling i dag. Henvisning til CT-angiografi/MR-angiografi av halskar SAMME DAG. Dokumentér grundig.

Differential diagnoses for Hallux Valgus?

Genetics (63-90% heritability)

 Twin studies show a strong hereditary component. If parents have hallux valgus, the risk is
 significantly higher.

Footwear

 Tight, pointed shoes and high heels significantly increase risk. High heels shift 70-80% of body weight
 to the forefoot.

Ligament laxity (hypermobility)

 Allows increased movement in the MTP joint that predisposes to deformity.

Flat foot (pes planus)

 Overpronation leads to increased loading on the inside of the big toe. See also tibialis posterior tendinopathy which can cause
 acquired flat foot.

Describe symptoms in adults for Scheuermann's Disease.

Symptoms in Adults

 When the skeleton is fully developed, treatment goals change. The structural kyphosis cannot
 be reversed, but symptoms, function, and quality of life can be significantly improved.

 The symptom picture in adults is often more complex than in adolescents
 Chronic or recurrent pain between the shoulder
 blades 

 Morning stiffness that improves with activity

 Reduced mobility in thoracic spine

 Muscle fatigue and tension (can resemble fibromyalgia-related chest pain )

 With curves over 75 degrees: reduced breathing capacity and endurance (see breathing, stress and back )

 Aesthetic concerns for some

 Uplifting News

 A Swedish study of older men (69-81 years) with Scheuermann's disease found no increased
 incidence of neck or back pain compared to peers without the condition (Jonsson et al.,
 Acta Orthop, 2023). As many as 25% of adults with Scheuermann's report actually no back
 pain.

What is the prognosis for Headache on Top of the Head?

Prognosis

 

 Most people with headache on top of the head have a good prognosis. Tension headache and neck-related causes often respond well to treatment.

 Short-term

 Good probability of improvement with treatment - one study found that 72% of patients with cervicogenic headache maintained at least 50% reduction in headache frequency after 12 months.

 Relapses are Common

 Headache tends to return, especially with persistent risk factors like stress and static work. This does not mean treatment has failed - it means prevention and self-management are important.

 Long-term

 Evidence suggests that different treatments often give similar results over time. The most important factor for sustained improvement appears to be regular exercises and lifestyle changes.

Describe The Chiropractor's Role for ICR Syndrome.

The Chiropractor's Role

 

 As a chiropractor, my most important role with ICR syndrome is to recognize warning symptoms and refer appropriately. ICR syndrome can resemble jaw pain and other musculoskeletal conditions, but requires different management:

 
 History: Identify symptoms that may indicate vascular pathology

 Red flags: Identify warning symptoms for dissection or temporal arteritis

 Referral: Send to emergency department or GP for further investigation

 Caution: Avoid neck manipulation when vascular pathology is suspected

 

 
 Important warning symptoms to watch for

 
 New onset one-sided neck/headache

 Horner's syndrome (drooping eyelid, small pupil)

 Pulsatile tinnitus

 Age over 50 with new headaches + jaw claudication

 Symptoms after neck trauma

 Transient neurological symptoms

 
 

 
 Contraindications for neck manipulation

 
 Suspected carotid or vertebral artery dissection

 Recent neurological symptoms

 Known atherosclerosis or aneurysm in neck vessels

 Ongoing anticoagulation treatment for vascular causes

 
 When in doubt - don't treat. Refer for investigation first.

Describe treatment options for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

Treatment

 

 This is the key message: 75-90% of patients with cervical disc herniation and
 radiculopathy improve significantly without surgery. Danish national guidelines from 2017 recommend
 manual treatment combined with exercises as first choice, before medication is considered.

 What can the chiropractor do?

 A systematic review from 2021 found that manual treatment showed effect in all included studies,
 regardless of technique. The consensus is that the combination of manual therapy and exercises gives
 better results than each treatment alone.

 
 Treatment may include:

 
 Joint mobilization of cervical vertebrae and upper back

 Soft tissue treatment of tight muscles in neck and shoulder

 Neural mobilization (gentle movement of the nerve along its path)

 Exercise instruction - strength and stability, especially deep neck flexors

 Ergonomic guidance and workstation adjustment

 
 

 What can you do yourself?

 
 Stay active - avoid prolonged bed rest

 Exercises - do the exercises your practitioner gives you regularly

 Ergonomics - adjust screen, chair and work position

 Pillow - a supportive pillow that keeps the neck in neutral position

 Heat or cold - experiment with what gives the best relief

 

 Treatment course

 
 Acute phase (0-4 weeks): 2-3 treatments per week, focus on pain relief and mobility
 

 Rehabilitation phase (4-12 weeks): 1-2 treatments per week, increasing focus on
 self-exercises and function

 Maintenance: As needed. Guidelines reco...

 Infraspinatus is one of four rotator cuff muscles and the second most common to
 injure. The muscle lies on the back of the shoulder blade and is responsible for external
 rotation of the shoulder.

 
 Pain behind the shoulder, may radiate toward the elbow

 Worsens with external rotation against resistance

 Often related to swimming, throwing and overhead activity

 
 

 
 
 Internal impingement

 

 Occurs when the rotator cuff (especially infraspinatus and supraspinatus) gets pinched against the
 posterior labrum when the arm is in "throwing position" (abducted and maximally externally rotated).
 

 
 Pain behind the shoulder in the "late cocking" phase of throwing

 Common in baseball pitchers, handball players, volleyball - similar mechanics as in thrower's shoulder

 Can cause secondary damage to labrum and rotator cuff

 
 

 
 
 GIRD (Glenohumeral Internal Rotation Deficit)

 

 Deficit in internal rotation of the shoulder, common in throwing athletes. 72% of handball players
 have GIRD. Often caused by tightening of the posterior shoulder capsule.

 
 Reduced internal rotation compared to the opposite side

 Increased external rotation (as compensation)

 Increased risk of shoulder problems and injuries

 
 

 
 Other causes

 
 Teres minor tendinopathy: Similar picture to infraspinatus

 Posterior labrum injury: Often together with internal impingement, can develop
 into...

Explain Posterior Canal BPPV: When the World Spins Backwards to a patient.

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a mechanical disorder of the inner ear's balance system. The condition occurs when small calcium crystite (otoliths) detach from their normal position in the utricle and migrate into one of the three semicircular canals.

 The posterior semicircular canal is the most commonly affected canal, accounting for 60-90% of all BPPV cases (Frontiers in Neurology, 2023). This is due to the anatomical position of the canals - the posterior canal is positioned lowest both when standing and lying down, so gravity naturally pulls loose crystals there.

 BPPV is the most common cause of vestibular dizziness and accounts for 20-30% of all dizziness consultations (StatPearls, 2022). The lifetime prevalence is approximately 2.4%, and women are affected twice as often as men.

You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Teeth Grinding (Bruxism).

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between sleep bruxism and awake bruxism?

 Sleep bruxism occurs unconsciously at night with rhythmic grinding movements (50-80 kg force), while awake bruxism is daytime clenching often linked to stress and concentration. They require different treatment.

 

 
 Can SSRI medications cause teeth grinding?

 Yes. Studies show 20-24% of SSRI users develop bruxism, vs 2-10% in the general population. Symptoms often start 3-4 weeks after starting. Talk to your doctor if you suspect a connection.

 

 
 Is there a connection between sleep apnea and teeth grinding?

 Yes, research shows that up to 50% of sleep apnea patients also have bruxism. Grinding may be a protective mechanism to open airways. Therefore, sleep apnea should be ruled out before treating with night guard.

 

 
 Does a night guard help with bruxism?

 Night guard protects teeth but doesn't reduce the grinding itself. With sleep apnea, night guard can actually worsen the condition by pushing the jaw backward. The guard should be combined with cause-based treatment.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor treat bruxism?

 Yes, chiropractors can treat the muscle and joint component of bruxism through jaw joint mobilization, neck treatment and trigger therapy in jaw muscles. I often collaborate with dentists.

Describe What is Calcific Tendinitis? for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

What is Calcific Tendinitis?

 

 Calcific tendinitis is a condition where calcium crystals deposit in the rotator cuff tendons, most
 commonly in the supraspinatus tendon. The deposits vary in size from small dots to lumps several
 centimeters large.

 The condition goes through several phases and is self-limiting - meaning the calcium
 will eventually be reabsorbed by the body. The problem is that this can take anywhere from a few months
 to several years, and in the meantime, the pain can be significant.

 How common is calcific tendinitis?

 Calcific tendinitis is one of the most common causes of shoulder pain:

 
 
 2.7-7.8%
 prevalence in population
 

 
 2x
 women affected more often
 

 
 40-60 years
 typical age group
 

 
 10-20%
 have it in both shoulders
 

 

 
 Who gets calcific tendinitis?

 
 Women are affected twice as often as men

 Most common between 40 and 60 years

 Often the non-dominant shoulder (left for right-handed people)

 Increased prevalence with metabolic disorders (diabetes, thyroid)

 Sedentary work may be a risk factor

What is the prognosis for Flat Back (Hypokyphosis)?

Prognosis

 

 Untreated hypokyphosis

 A 30-year follow-up study found that patients with hypokyphosis had 10 times increased risk of needing
 neck surgery compared to those with normal kyphosis (MDPI, 2022).

 With treatment

 
 Available case reports show that structural improvement is possible - average 10-14 degrees increase in
 kyphosis in motivated patients. Pain often reduces significantly.

 

 Realistic expectations

 Treatment evidence is very limited. Not everyone will have the same benefit, and some structural changes
 cannot be reversed. The goal is often to improve function and reduce symptoms.

Explain chiropractic approach - with important caveats for Dysautonomia.

Chiropractic Approach - With Important Caveats

 Evidence Level: Limited (case reports)

 There are no RCTs specifically examining chiropractic treatment of dysautonomia. A published case report (PMC 2022) described a 50-year-old woman with POTS who reported complete symptom relief after three months of multicomponent chiropractic rehabilitation, but individual cases cannot be generalized.

 The chiropractor's role in dysautonomia is primarily
 Identify: Recognize symptom patterns that may indicate autonomic dysfunction

 Assess: Active standing test, cervical examination, VNG for vestibular symptoms

 Manage the musculoskeletal component: Cervical treatment for neck pain and stiffness, thoracic treatment, soft tissue techniques

 Refer: To GP for blood tests, neurologist for tilt-table test, cardiologist for cardiac issues

 Collaborate: As part of a multidisciplinary team, not as the sole practitioner

 Chiropractic treatment is not a treatment for dysautonomia itself, but can be a supplement to medical follow-up and graded exercise for patients where musculoskeletal factors play a role.

Describe symptoms and diagnosis for Medication Overuse Headache.

Symptoms and Diagnosis

 The MOH diagnosis is made when the following criteria are met (ICHD-3)
 Diagnostic Criteria

 Headache 15+ days per month in a patient with known primary headache

 Regular overuse of acute headache medications for more than 3 months

 The headache cannot be better explained by another diagnosis

 Typical Characteristics

 Daily or almost daily headache - often present upon waking

 Mixed character - may resemble both migraine and tension headache

 Fear of headache - takes medication "preventively" before the pain comes

 Escalation need - must take higher doses for the same effect

 The headache "breaks through" the medication faster than before

 Medications work less well over time

 Who is Most at Risk?

 Women (3-4x higher risk)

What causes Thoracic Back Pain – Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

3 Common Causes of Thoracic Back Pain

 Most thoracic back pain is caused by mechanical issues that can be effectively treated by a chiropractor:

 
 Rib Joint Dysfunction (Costovertebral Dysfunction)

 The most common cause of thoracic back pain. Occurs when the joints between the ribs and vertebrae become stiff or "locked."

 
 Sharp pain with breathing and movement

 Point tenderness at the rib attachment

 Often triggered by twisting or lifting

 Responds very well to chiropractic treatment

 
 

 
 Costochondritis

 Inflammation in the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone. Causes pain at the front of the chest but often related to thoracic dysfunction.

 
 Tender to touch at the breastbone

 Can mimic heart pain

 Worse with coughing and deep breathing

 Often self-limiting, but treatment helps

 
 

 
 Thoracic Facet Joint Dysfunction

 Stiffness or irritation in the small joints between the vertebrae in the thoracic spine.

 
 Stiff and aching pain between the shoulder blades

 Worse with extension (bending backward)

 Often related to poor posture

 Common in office workers

 
 

 
 Myofascial Trigger Points

 Painful knots in the muscles, especially in the rhomboids, trapezius, and erector spinae.

 
 Often refer pain to other areas

 Can cause headaches and neck pain

 Often related to stress and overload

 Treated effectively with soft tissue treatment

 
 

 
 Poor Posture and Ergonomics

 Prolonged poor loading from office work, mobile phone use, or on...

Beskriv diagnostikk for Rotator Cuff — Komplett Guide til Rotatorkuffen.

Diagnostikk

 En grundig klinisk undersokelse er fundamentet for diagnosen. Bildediagnostikk er ofte unodvendig for a starte behandling.

 Kliniske tester

 Jobe's test (Empty Can)

 Tester supraspinatus. Armen loftes med tommelen ned. Smerte eller svakhet er positivt funn. Sensitivitet ca. 70-80%.

 Utadrotasjon med motstand

 Tester infraspinatus og teres minor. Albuen i 90 grader, roter utover mot motstand. Svakhet tyder pa bakre rotatorcuff-affeksjon.

 Lift-off test / Bear-hug test

 Tester subscapularis. Handen plasseres bak ryggen (lift-off) eller pa motsatt skulder (bear-hug). Svakhet tyder pa subscapularis-affeksjon.

 Drop arm test

 Armen holdes passivt loftet ut til siden. Hvis pasienten ikke klarer a senke armen kontrollert, tyder det pa fulltykkelse-ruptur. Hoy spesifisitet.

 Bildediagnostikk

 Ultralyd vs. MR

 Ultralyd er et godt forstvalg for a vurdere rotatorkuffen. Det er billig, tilgjengelig, og har sammenlignbar noyaktighet med MR for a pavis rupturer. Ulempen er at kvaliteten avhenger av undersokeren.

 MR gir mer detaljert informasjon om rupturens storrelse, muskelkvalitet (fettinfiltrasjon) og andre strukturer. MR er mest aktuelt nar kirurgi vurderes.

 Nar er bildediagnostikk aktuelt?

 Bildediagnostikk vurderes ved: akutt traume med svakhet, mistanke om stor ruptur, manglende bedring etter 6-12 uker med trening, eller nar kirurgi vurderes. For de fleste er klinisk undersokelse tilstrekkelig for a starte behandling.

Describe symptoms and signs of Acute Back Pain (Lumbago) - Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Symptoms of Acute Back Pain

 

 Symptoms of acute back pain are typically localized to the lower back and can vary in intensity:

 Characteristic symptoms:

 
 Acute pain: Sudden onset, often described as "stabbing" or "paralyzing"

 Stiffness: Significantly reduced mobility in the back

 Muscle tension: Often palpable tension in the back muscles

 Pain intensification: Movement, coughing, sneezing, and straining worsen the pain
 

 Relief at rest: Pain often decreases in stationary positions

 

 
 Important distinction: Uncomplicated vs. Complicated

 In uncomplicated acute back pain, the pain is limited to the lower back without radiating symptoms to
 the legs. If you experience radiating pain, numbness, or weakness in the legs, this may indicate nerve
 involvement (sciatica) and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.

Describe Important to know in the context of Pain in Arm, Elbow and Hand.

Golfer's elbow (medial epicondylitis)

 7-10x rarer than tennis elbow
 

 Go to full article on golfer's elbow →

 Golfer's elbow is like tennis elbow, except the pain is on the inside of the elbow. The condition is
 7-10 times rarer than tennis elbow and affects 0.4-1% of the population. Over 90% of cases are
 due to work-related strain - tradespeople, carpenters, plumbers and butchers are far more
 often affected than golfers.

 
 Important to know

 The ulnar nerve runs just behind the tender area. 20-60% of patients with golfer's
 elbow have concurrent nerve irritation causing tingling in the ring and little finger. This can
 significantly prolong treatment time.

Describe treatment options for ICR Syndrome.

Treatment

 

 Treatment depends entirely on the underlying cause:

 
 
 Carotid Dissection

 

 
 Antithrombotic treatment: Blood thinners (anticoagulation or antiplatelet)

 Hospitalization: For monitoring and acute treatment

 Endovascular treatment: Stenting if needed

 Duration: Antithrombotic treatment for 3-6 months

 
 

 
 
 TIPIC / Idiopathic Carotidynia

 

 
 NSAIDs: Ibuprofen or naproxen

 Steroids: If NSAIDs are insufficient

 Prognosis: Often self-limiting over weeks

 
 

 
 
 Temporal Arteritis

 

 
 High-dose steroids: Started immediately on suspicion

 Biopsy: Of temporal artery to confirm diagnosis

 Long-term treatment: Tapering over months to years

Hva er prognosen for Fibromyalgi med Brystsmerter?

Prognose - Hvordan går det?

 

 Fibromyalgi er en kronisk tilstand. En 10-Ørs oppfølgsstudie (Wolfe et al., 1996) viste at 100% hadde fortsatt noen symptomer, men 66% opplevde bedring. Remisjon forekommer hos 17-47% etter 1-2 Ør med aktiv behandling.

 Faktorer som bedrer prognosen:

 
 
 Trening
 Den viktigste modifiserbare faktoren
 

 
 Tidlig
 diagnose og helhetlig behandling
 

 
 Søvn
 Behandling av depresjon og søvnproblemer

Beskriv Kjennetegn på karpaltunnelsyndrom i kontekst av Nummenhet i fingrene - Nakke eller hand?.

Kjennetegn på karpaltunnelsyndrom

 
 Fingre påvirket: Tommel, pekefinger, langfinger, og halve ringfinger

 Verre om natten: Mange vakner av nummenhet og må riste på handen

 Lindres ved risting: å riste på handen gir ofte kortvarig lindring

 Ingen nakkesmerte: Symptomene er lokalisert til hand og underarm

 Risikofaktorer: Graviditet, diabetes, hypothyreose, repetitivt arbeid

 Svakhet: Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan tommelmuskulaturen bli svakere

 
 

 Ulnarisnerveaffeksjon (Cubitaltunnelsyndrom)

 Ulnarisnerven kan bli klemt ved albuen (cubitaltunnelen) eller ved handleddet (Guyons kanal).

 
 Kjennetegn på ulnarispåvirkning

 
 Fingre påvirket: Lillefinger og halve ringfinger (ulnare halvdel)

 Albueposisjon: Ofte verre ved bøyning av albuen eller ved å hvile på albuen

 Innsiden av handen: Kan gi svakhet i de små handmusklene

 "Klofingre": Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan fingrene få kloliknende stilling

 
 

 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS)

 Nervene og blodarene til armen kan bli klemt i området mellom nakkebasis og armhulen.

 
 Kjennetegn på TOS

 
 Nummenhet og prikking i hele handen eller flere fingre

 Ofte forverret av å holde armene over hodet

 Kan gi kuldefølelse og fargeforandringer i handen

 Ofte forbundet med dårlig holdning eller ekstra nakkeribben

Document Gonstead cervical chair adjustment for C5 subluxation.

Gonstead cervical analysis C5:

Nervoscope: Temperature differential C5 right.
Static palpation: Edema and tenderness C5 articular pillar right.
Motion palpation: C5 body left (C5-BL) — restricted rotation right.
X-ray: C5-BL listing confirmed on APOM view.

Adjustment:
- C5-BL: Cervical chair adjustment.
  Patient seated, head tilted slightly left.
  Contact: Right lamina/articular pillar C5.
  LOD: L→R, P→A.
  Stabilizing hand: Left mastoid.
  Specific HVLA rotatory thrust.
- Post-check: Temperature equalized, improved right rotation, patient reports reduced stiffness immediately.

Rode flagg — Nar er det akutt?

 Akutte varselsignaler — Sok hjelp UMIDDELBART

 Folgende symptomer ved mistenkt cervikal myelopati krever akutt medisinsk vurdering 
 Ring 113 eller dra til legevakt

 Raskt progredierende svakhet i armer og/eller ben over dager til uker

 Hvorfor haster det?

 Ryggmargen har begrenset evne til a reparere seg selv . Langvarig kompresjon kan gi varige skader pa nerveceller og ledningsbaner.  Ogsa grunn til rask henvisning (dager-uker)

 Gradvis oknde problemer med a ga, saerlig pa ujevnt underlag

 Tiltagende klossethet i hendene over uker til maneder

 Progresjon av nummenhet eller prikking

 Nye ovre motornevron-tegn (hyperrefleksi, Babinski, klonus)

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over PIFP: Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte.

Definisjon og terminologi: Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte (PIFP) defineres av ICHD-3 (International Classification of Headache Disorders) som
ICHD-3 Diagnostiske kriterier: For diagnose må alle følgende kriterier våre oppfylt
Hvem rammes?: PIFP er en relativt sjelden tilstand, men er trolig underdiagnostisert fordi mange pasienter går lange løp hos ulike spesialister for de får riktig diagnose.

Patofysiologi - Hvorfor oppstår PIFP?: Den eksakte mekanismen bak PIFP er ukjent, men flere teorier finnes
Klinisk presentasjon: Mange pasienter har en karakteristisk bakgrunn med smertedebut etter dental prosedyre (ekstraksjon, rotfylling, implantat), ofte multiple tannbehandlinger i forsøk på lindring, gjentatte konsultasjoner uten diagnose, og frustrasjon over å ikke bli trodd.

Differensialdiagnoser: PIFP er en eksklusjonsdiagnose. Følgende må utelukkes
Behandling: Unngå ytterligere invasive prosedyrer! Tannekstraksjoner eller kirurgi gjør ofte situasjonen verre, ikke bedre. Mange PIFP-pasienter har allerede gjennomgått multiple unødvendige inngrep.

Kiropraktorens rolle: PIFP responderer vanligvis ikke godt på manuell behandling alene. Medikamentell behandling er ofte nødvendig, og psykologisk støtte er viktig for mange pasienter.

Prognose: PIFP er ofte en kronisk tilstand, men med riktig behandling kan de fleste oppnå betydelig bedring.

Skriv subjektiv del av SOAP-notat for en pasient med Svimmel når du legger deg? Dette bør du vite om krystallsyke.

Krystallsyke - eller BPPV (benign paroksysmal posisjonsvertigo) - er den vanligste årsaken til at man blir svimmel når man legger seg ned eller endrer hodestilling. Tilstanden skyldes at små kalkpartikler (otolitter) har løsnet fra sin normale plass i det indre øret og kommet på avveie i buegangene.

 Disse krystallene forstyrrer væskestrømningen i buegangene når du beveger hodet. Det gir hjernen motstridende signaler om kroppens stilling, og resultatet er en kortvarig, men intens følelse av at

Explain rotator cuff strengthening exercises for Shoulder Exercises.

Rotator cuff strengthening exercises

 Rotator cuff strength is the foundation of a stable shoulder. Research shows that eccentric training provides significant medium-term pain relief (SMD: -0.57), and motor control exercises reduce disability compared to non-specific training.

 External rotation with band

 Most important 

 Stand with your elbow at your side, bent 90 degrees

 Hold a resistance band anchored at a door handle or similar

 Rotate your forearm outward to the side — keep the elbow still

 Return slowly (the eccentric phase is the most important)

 Dosing: 3 sets x 12-15 repetitions, every other day.

 Progression: Increase resistance with a thicker band when 15 reps feel easy.

 Internal rotation with band

 Same starting position as above, but band anchored on the opposite side

 Rotate your forearm inward toward your stomach

 Control the movement slowly back

 Dosing: 3 sets x 12-15 repetitions, every other day.

 Isometric resistance in 4 directions

 Stand at a wall or doorframe

 Push against the surface in 4 directions: forward, backward, outward, inward

 Hold each push for 10 seconds without moving the arm

 Use approximately 50-70% of maximum effort

 Dosing: 5 repetitions per direction, twice daily.

 Especially useful: In the acute phase when dynamic exercise provokes pain.

 Scapular retractions

 Sit or stand with arms at your sides

 Squeeze your shoulder blades together and down — think "put them in your back pockets"

 Hold for 5 seconds

 Release slowly

 Dosing: 3 sets x 15 repetitions, daily.

Prognosis - How Does It Progress?

 

 With proper treatment, most experience significant improvement. Patients on preventive treatment see reduction in both frequency, intensity, and duration of attacks.

 Realistic Expectations

 
 Relapses are common: Even with good treatment, many will experience periods with more attacks

 Treatment takes time: It may take 2-3 months before preventive medications have full effect

 Individual variation: What works for one person does not necessarily work for another

 

 The positive news is that many find that attacks become less intense and less frequent over the years, especially with good treatment and trigger management. In some cases, prolonged vestibular migraine can develop into PPPD (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness), which requires a different treatment approach.

Explain treatment for Trigger Points and Myofascial Pain Syndrome in the Neck.

Treatment

 What can the chiropractor do?

 A network meta-analysis from 2024 shows that manual therapy provides short-term improvement in pain, pressure sensitivity, and function.

 Ischemic compression: Sustained pressure on the trigger point provides significant improvement in pressure pain threshold

 Dry needling: Thin needles are inserted directly into the trigger point. Equally effective as manual trigger point treatment in the short and medium term

 Myofascial techniques and mobilization: Soft tissue treatment of muscles and fascia

 Joint mobilization/manipulation: For concurrent joint dysfunction in the neck or thoracic spine

 What can you do yourself?

 A systematic review shows that combined stretching and strength training provides the best effect on myofascial pain
 Stretching: Hold for 30 seconds - this is the optimal duration according to research. Stretch trapezius, levator scapulae, and scalenes daily

 Strength training: Exercises for deep neck muscles and shoulder blade stabilizers

 Ergonomics: Screen at eye level, forearms supported, regular breaks. Avoid forward head posture

 Self-massage: Use a tennis ball or lacrosse ball against the wall for gentle pressure on tender points. 30-60 seconds per point

 Stress management: Chronic stress maintains muscle tension. Consider breathing techniques or mindfulness

 Short-term effects of treatment are well documented. For lasting effect, it's important to combine treatment with self-exercise and to address underlying factors such as stress, ergonomics, and sleep.

Describe causes and risk factors for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Causes and risk factors

 Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs when pressure in the tunnel becomes too high. This can be caused by
 Swelling of the tendons (most common)

 Repetitive strain or overuse can cause swelling in the tendon sheaths passing through the tunnel,
 reducing space for the nerve.

 Hormonal factors

 Pregnancy, menopause, hypothyroidism and diabetes increase risk through fluid retention and tissue
 swelling.

 Anatomical factors

 Some people naturally have narrower carpal tunnels. Previous wrist fractures can also narrow the
 tunnel.

 Repetitive work

 Office work, cashier work, production work - anything with repeated hand movements over time. See also
 mouse arm .

 Important risk factors

 Gender: Women are affected 3 times more often than men

 Pregnancy: Common in the last trimester (fluid retention)

 Diabetes: Increased risk of nerve disease in general

 Obesity: BMI over 30 significantly increases risk

 Arthritis: Inflammation can affect the tendon sheaths

 Hereditary: Tends to run in families

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Foot and Ankle Problems.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Do I need a referral?

 No. Chiropractors have primary contact status in Norway. You can book an appointment directly without a
 referral from a doctor.

 

 
 Can you refer me onwards?

 Yes. I can refer to X-ray, MRI, CT and ultrasound covered by National Insurance. I can also refer to
 physiotherapy and specialists (orthopaedic surgeon, rheumatologist, neurologist).

 

 
 Can I get a sick note?

 Yes, chiropractors with documented competence can issue sick notes for up to 12 weeks.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 It varies by condition: Ankle sprain grade I-II: 1-6 weeks. Plantar fasciopathy: 6-12 weeks active
 treatment (80-90% better within 12 months). Metatarsalgia: 6-8 weeks. Achilles tendinopathy: 6-12
 months. Morton's neuroma: 3-6 months with conservative treatment.

 

 
 Can I train while in treatment?

 Often yes - The goal is "optimal loading": enough load to stimulate healing, but not so much that you
 worsen the injury. Complete rest is rarely the solution. I give specific advice tailored to your situation.

 

 
 Do insoles help?

 Can provide relief for some, but evidence is moderate. Important: prefabricated insoles work just as
 well as expensive custom-made ones for plantar fasciopathy. Stretching and strength training have better documentation.

Describe What about headache and bite? for Bite Problems and Jaw Pain - Myths vs Facts.

What about headache and bite?

 

 The connection between malocclusion and headache is also poorly documented. Van der Meer and colleagues concluded in Cephalalgia (2019) that primary headaches like tension headache and migraine "are not caused by musculoskeletal dysfunction" - even though they may be associated with such symptoms.

 The International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3) recognizes "headache attributed to temporomandibular dysfunction" as secondary headache. But this relates to TMD itself - not to bite deviation directly.

Pasient spør: "Hvorfor gir nakkebehandling hodepinelette?"

Nakken og hodet deler nerveforbindelser via den trigeminocervikale kjernen. Nervesignaler fra de overste nakkesegmentene (C1-C3) konvergerer med signaler fra trigeminusnerven i ansiktet. Behandling av nakken kan dempe disse signalene og redusere hodepine (Bogduk 2001).

Describe the most common causes of dizziness for You Don't Have to Live With Dizziness Anymore.

The Most Common Causes of Dizziness

 BPPV - Vertigo

 BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) is the most common cause of rotational dizziness and accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness cases. The condition occurs when small calcium particles dislodge in the inner ear and end up in the semicircular canals.

 Typical characteristics: Brief, intense dizziness episodes (seconds to one minute) triggered by head movements - such as turning in bed, bending down, or looking up.

 Treatment response: Studies show 80-90% improvement with repositioning maneuvers like Epley. Many experience improvement after one treatment, while others need 2-3 treatments. Success rate after repeated treatments is over 90-95%.

 Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related)

 Studies show that up to 40% of patients with neck pain also experience dizziness. The upper cervical vertebrae (C1-C3) contain a high concentration of position sense receptors that send information to the brain about head position. When these signals are disturbed, the result can be unsteadiness and dizziness.

 Typical characteristics: Persistent unsteadiness that worsens with neck movements, often combined with neck pain and headache.

 Treatment response: A systematic review from 2011 concluded that there is moderate evidence for manual treatment of cervicogenic dizziness. Treatment is often combined with specific exercises.

 Vestibular Neuritis

 An inflammation of the balance nerve, often after a viral infection. Causes sudden, intense dizziness that lasts for days to weeks.

 Treatment response: Vestibular rehabilitation shows significant effect. A Cochrane review found statistically significant improvement compared to no treatment.

 Other Causes

 Vestibular migraine, Meniere's disease, medication side effects, and orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure drop when standing) are among other common causes. Sometimes multiple conditions overlap.

Patient asks: "Is a labral tear the same as hip osteoarthritis?"

No, but they can be related. Labral tear affects the cartilage rim around the hip socket, while osteoarthritis is wear of the joint cartilage. Untreated labral tear can over time increase the risk of osteoarthritis, but many with labral tears never develop osteoarthritis.

Prognose: Hvor lang tid tar det?

 Prognosen ved C5-C6 prolaps er generelt god. Forskning viser at det store flertallet blir bra med konservativ behandling, uten behov for kirurgi (Caridi et al., 2011; Radhakrishnan et al., 1994).

 85% 
 betydelig bedring uten kirurgi 

 2-4 
 uker til første merkbar bedring 

 8-12 
 uker median tid til betydelig bedring 

 Hva påvirker prognosen?

 Gode prognostiske faktorer

 Tidlig behandlingsstart

 Ung alder (under 50)

 Hovedsakelig radikular smerte (armsmerte dominerer)

 Ingen alvorlige nevrologiske utfall

 God funksjon i hverdagen tross smerte

 Faktorer som kan forlenge forløpet

 Forsinket behandlingsstart

 Samtidig depresjon eller angst

 Katastrofetanker om smerten

 Passiv mestringsstrategi (unngaelse, sengeleie)

 Langvarig nakkestivhet for symptomstart

 Kan prolapsen krympe?

 Ja. Diskprolapser kan faktisk reabsorberes over tid. Kroppen har en bemerkelsesverdig evne til å bryte ned og fjerne det utstikkende skivematerialet. Inflammasjonen rundt nerven avtar gradvis, og symptomene bedres ofte for selve prolapsen er helt borte.

 Studier viser at større prolapser (sekvestrerte) faktisk har bedre reabsorpsjonsrate enn mindre buklinger, fordi immunsystemet lettere "oppdager" og bryter ned det løse skivematerialet.

Patient asks: "How do I know if my rib is broken or just dislocated?"

The most important clue is the trauma history. With a fracture, you remember exactly what happened - a fall, a blow, an accident. With dislocation, the history is often more vague. The intensity is also different - fractures typically cause more intense pain that makes it difficult to take deep breaths.

Beskriv årsaker og risikofaktorer for Karpaltunnelsyndrom: Komplett guide.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Karpaltunnelsyndrom oppstår når trykket i tunnelen blir for høyt. Dette kan skyldes
 Hevelse av senene (vanligst)

 Repetitiv belastning eller overbruk kan føre til hevelse i senerørene som går gjennom tunnelen, og redusere plassen til nerven.

 Hormonelle faktorer

 Graviditet, overgangsalder, hypothyreose og diabetes øker risikoen gjennom væskeopphopning og vevshevelse.

 Anatomiske faktorer

 Noen har naturlig trangere karpaltunnel. Tidligere handleddsbrudd kan også trange tunnelen.

 Repetitivt arbeid

 Kontorarbeid, kassaarbeid, produksjonsarbeid - alt med gjentatte handbevegelser over tid. Se også musearm .

 Viktige risikofaktorer

 Kjénn: Kvinner rammes 3 ganger oftere enn menn

 Graviditet: Vanlig i siste trimester (væskeopphopning)

 Diabetes: Økt risiko for nervesykdom generelt

 Overvekt: BMI over 30 Øker risikoen betydelig

 Leddgikt: Betennelse kan påvirke seneskedene

 Arvelig: Tendens til å gå i familier
