Describe causes and risk factors for Scapular Pain and Cervical Radiculopathy.

2 Causes and Risk Factors

 Why do neck problems cause scapular pain?

 The nerves from the neck (C4-C8) have branches that innervate the muscles and skin around the shoulder blades. When a nerve root is irritated, the pain may be felt where the nerve ends - not where the problem originates.

 From most to least common

 Muscular tension/myofascial pain: Trigger points in rhomboids and trapezius. Most common. Often related to office work

 Cervical referred pain/radiculopathy: Underdiagnosed. Should be suspected when pain worsens with neck movements

 Thoracic spine dysfunction: Stiffness in thoracic spine segments and costovertebral dysfunction

 Shoulder pathology: Scapular dyskinesis, rotator cuff 

 Visceral referred pain: Heart disease (left shoulder blade), gallstones (right shoulder blade) - rare but important to rule out

 Which neck levels cause scapular pain?

 Mizutamari et al. (2011) mapped pain patterns in 180 patients
 C5: Above the shoulder blade (suprascapular)

 C6: From the top of the shoulder blade toward the back of the shoulder

 C7: Between the shoulder blades (interscapular) - most common

 C8: Between and around the shoulder blades

Patient asks: "Is foraminal stenosis the same as sciatica?"

No. Both cause leg pain, but the causes are different. Sciatica is most often caused by a disc herniation, while foraminal stenosis is caused by age-related narrowing of the nerve opening. Treatment also differs.

Beskriv Hva er en SLAP-lesjon? for SLAP-lesjon: Alt du trenger å vite.

Hva er en SLAP-lesjon?

 

 SLAP-lesjon er en skade på den Øvre delen av labrum (leddlepen) i skulderleddet, der den lange bicepssenen fester seg. "SLAP" star for "Superior Labrum Anterior to Posterior" - altså en skade som strekker seg fra foran til bak på den Øvre leddlepen.

 Labrum er en bruskring som omgir leddfaten i skulderen og bidrar til stabiliteten. Den lange bicepssenen fester seg på toppen av denne ringen, og det er her SLAP-lesjoner oppstår.

 Klassifikasjon

 SLAP-lesjoner klassifiseres i fire hovedtyper:

 
 
 Type I - Degenerative forandringer

 

 Slitasje og frynser i labrum uten avløsning. Vanlig aldersforandring. Krever sjelden behandling.

 

 
 
 Type II - Avløsning av labrum og bicepsfeste

 Vanligst
 

 Labrum og bicepsfestet loster fra leddfaten. Dette er den mest klinisk relevante typen og den som oftest diskuteres i forhold til kirurgi.

 

 
 
 Type III - "Botte-hank"-rift

 

 En del av labrum rives av og kan henge ned i leddet som en botte-hank. Kan gi mekaniske symptomer.

 

 
 
 Type IV - Rift som involverer bicepssenen

 

 Kombinasjon av type III med at riftten strekker seg inn i bicepssenen.

 

 
 
 6%
 av skulderartroskopier
 

 
 Type II
 vanligste type
 

 
 20-40 Ør
 typisk aldersgruppe

Fordelene med kortison

 

 Kortison har sin plass i behandlingen av skulderplager. Her er situasjonene der det kan våre nyttig:

 
 Når kortison kan våre et godt valg

 
 Akutt, intens betennelse: Når smerten er så kraftig at du ikke klarer å gjøre Øvelser

 opplever initial bedring

 tid til effekt

 typisk varighet
 

 

 
 Kortison som "vindusÅpner"

Describe Referred pain - pain in the wrong place for Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm.

Referred pain - pain in the wrong place

 

 The most confusing thing about trigger points is referred pain: pain is felt in a
 completely different place from where the problem is. This explains why many get the wrong diagnosis.

 
 Common referred pain patterns in the arm

 
 Extensors (top of forearm): Referred pain to elbow and back of hand - resembles tennis elbow

 Flexors (underside of forearm): Referred pain to wrist and fingers - resembles carpal tunnel

 Brachioradialis: Referred pain to thumb base and wrist

 Scalene muscles (neck): Referred pain down into arm and fingers - resembles
 radiculopathy

 Subscapularis (shoulder): Referred pain to wrist and back of upper arm

 
 

 
 Common misdiagnoses

 Because of referred pain, trigger points are often misdiagnosed as:

 
 Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis)

 Carpal tunnel syndrome

 Cervical radiculopathy (neck nerve root)

 De Quervain's tenosynovitis

 Frozen shoulder

Forklar behandling ved c6-c7 prolaps for C6.

Behandling ved C6-C7 prolaps

 Konservativ behandling er førstevalget og gir utmerkede resultater for de aller fleste. Målet er å redusere smerte, bevare funksjon og støttekroppens naturlige helingsprosess.

 Fase 1: Akutt smertehåndtering (uke 1-2)

 Aktivitetsmodifikasjon

 Unngånakkeekstensjon og rotasjon mot smertefull side

 Bruk nakkestøtteved behov under søvn

 Behold så normal aktivitet som mulig

 Kortvarig hvile er greit, men unngålangvarig inaktivitet

 Smertelindring

 NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) kan redusere inflammasjon

 Is eller varme etter preferanse

 Ved sterke smerter: kontakt lege for reseptbelagt smertelindring

 Fase 2: Manuell behandling og mobilisering (uke 2-8)

 Kiropraktisk behandling kan inkludere
 Leddmobilisering: Forsiktig gjenoppretting av bevegelse i nakkesegmentene

 Myofascial behandling: Løsne stram muskulatur i nakke, skulder og bryst

 Nervemobilisering: Forsiktig glid av C7-nerven for å redusere irritasjon

 Thorakal manipulasjon: Ofte godt tolerert og gir avlastning av nakken

 Fase 3: øvelser og rehabilitering

 Viktige øvelsestyper

 Nakkeretraksjoner: "Dobbelhake"-Øvelsen styrker dype nakkemuskler

 Isometriske øvelser: Styrke uten bevegelse i akutt fase

 Scapula-stabilisering: Styrke rundt skulderbladene avlaster nakken

 Nerveglidning: Forsiktig mobilisering av nervevevet

 Holdningskorrigering: Redusere fremoverlent hode

 Når vurderes kirurgi?

 Kirurgisk behandling (anterior cervikal diskektomi og fusjon - ACDF) er sjelden nødvendig.

 Kirurgiske indikasjoner

 Progressiv motorisk svakhet til tross for konservativ behandling

 Tegn på myelopati (ryggmargspåvirkning)

 Invalidiserende smerte etter 6-12 uker med adekvat behandling

 Betydelig funksjonstap i dagliglivet

 Kun 10-15% av pasienter trenger kirurgi.

Explain treatment - how to break the cycle for Medication Overuse Headache.

Treatment - How to Break the Cycle

 The most important treatment for MOH is discontinuation of the overused medications. This can be done abruptly or gradually, depending on which medications are being used.

 Step 1: Recognition and Preparation

 Many do not know they have MOH. The first step is to understand the connection between medication use and headache. Keep a headache diary for 4-8 weeks documenting
 Headache days and intensity

 All medications (type, dose, timing)

 Other factors (sleep, stress, menstruation)

 Step 2: Discontinuation

 Methods for Discontinuation

 Abrupt discontinuation: Recommended for triptans and common painkillers. Safe to do at home with good planning

 Gradual tapering: Recommended for opioids and combination preparations. Should be done under doctor supervision

 Hospitalization: For severe dependence or previous failed attempts

 Expect Rebound Headache

 The first 1-2 weeks after discontinuation, the headache will typically worsen significantly. This is normal and temporary. Other symptoms may include
 Nausea and vomiting

 Sleep difficulties

 Anxiety and restlessness

 Agitation

 These symptoms gradually subside and most notice clear improvement after 6-8 weeks.

 Step 3: Support Treatment During Discontinuation

 Fluids and rest: Drink plenty, rest when necessary

 Limited "rescue" medications: The doctor may prescribe a limited number for the worst days

 Preventive medication: Can be started at the same time as discontinuation

 Non-pharmacological measures: Ice/heat, relaxation, light activity

 Step 4: Relapse Prevention

 Lifestyle Changes to Prevent Relapse

 Headache diary: Continue keeping a diary to catch increased use early

 The 10-day rule: Never use acute painkillers more than 10 days per month

 The 2-3 day rule: Ideally max 2-3 days per week

 Regular sleep and meals 

 Physical activity: Has preventive effect on headache

 Stress management

Vurder røde flagg: 52 år mann med akutt debut av svakhet i begge bena, nummenhet fra brystlinjen og ned, og vannlatingsproblemer etter å ha løftet tungt. Kjent torakal diskusherniering.

HASTEGRAD: AKUTT — Ring 113

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Akutt torakal myelopati.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Bilateral beinsvakhet med sensorisk nivå ved brystlinjen = torakal medullakompresjon
- Kjent torakal diskusherniering = anatomisk årsak identifisert
- Vannlatingsproblemer = sfinkteraffeksjon (alvorlig prognostisk markør)
- Akutt debut etter løfting = mulig akutt diskusherniering
- Torakal medullakompresjon har DÅRLIGERE prognose enn lumbal CES pga. ryggmargen

Dette er AKUTT: ryggmargen tolererer kompresjon dårligere enn cauda equina.

HANDLING: Ring 113. Akutt MR torakalcolumna. Nevrokirurgisk vurdering for dekompresjon. INGEN manipulasjon. Fullstendig immobilisering av thorakalcolumna.

Beskriv Hvem bor du velge? for Kiropraktor vs Naprapat: Hva er forskjellen og hvem bor du velge?.

Hvem bor du velge?

 

 
 Velg kiropraktor hvis:

 
 Du kan trenge sykemelding - bare kiropraktor (sammen med lege og manuellterapeut) kan skrive sykemelding

 Du trenger bildediagnostikk - kiropraktorer kan rekvirere MR, rontgen og CT direkte uten at du ma via fastlegen

 Du vil ha en behandler som kan handtere det meste - kiropraktorens utvidede rettigheter betyr at du ofte slipper a ga via andre instanser

 Du har nevrologiske symptomer - kiropraktorens medisinske utdanning er spesielt relevant ved mistanke om nervepavirkning

 Du onsker kortere, mer fokuserte behandlinger - kiropraktisk tradisjon vektlegger effektive, malrettede intervensjoner

 
 

 
 Velg naprapat hvis:

 
 Du onsker lengre behandlingstid - naprapater bruker ofte mer tid per konsultasjon

 Du foretrekker mye muskelarbeid - naprapatisk tilnarming vektlegger ofte blotvevsbehandling

 Du liker myke teknikker - naprapater bruker generelt mykere mobiliseringsteknikker

 Du har hatt god erfaring med naprapat tidligere - personlig erfaring og relasjon med behandler er viktig

 
 

 
 Det viktigste: Finn en god behandler

 Uansett tittel er den individuelle behandlerens kompetanse og erfaring avgjorende. En dyktig naprapat kan gi bedre resultat enn en middelmadig kiropraktor - og omvendt.

 

 Spor gjerne om:

 
 Behandlerens erfaring med din type plage

 Hvordan de vurderer og behandler

 Hvor mange behandlinger de forventer

 For those who develop PCS, 77% show meaningful improvement with specialized treatment

 With active vestibular rehabilitation, most see significant improvement within 4-8 weeks

 Median duration of PCS is about 7 months, but about 12% have symptoms for more than 2 years

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Weak Feet: The Root Cause Most People Overlook.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does it take to strengthen the feet?

 Noticeable improvements are typically seen after 4-8 weeks of consistent training. The Liverpool study showed 57% strength increase after 6 months with minimalist shoes. Foot training should be viewed as maintenance - just like any other exercise.

 

 
 Is barefoot walking safe?

 For most people, gradual barefoot walking is safe and beneficial. Start indoors on soft surfaces and increase gradually. People with diabetes, neuropathy, or reduced sensation in their feet should be careful and consult a healthcare professional first.

 

 
 Can I train my feet even if I have flat feet?

 Yes, absolutely. Research (Huang 2022 meta-analysis) shows that foot training can increase arch strength and improve function even in people with flat feet. Flexible flat foot often responds well to strength training.

 

 
 Should I throw away my orthotics?

 Not necessarily. If you have diabetes, severe deformities, or specific medical indications, orthotics may still be important. For non-specific problems, gradual weaning combined with foot training may be a good alternative. Discuss with a professional.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with weak feet?

 Yes. Chiropractors assess the entire musculoskeletal system and can identify whether foot problems are due to local conditions or compensations from hips, pelvis, or back. Treatment often includes joint mobilization, soft tissue work, and guidance on targeted foo...

 Vanligste årsak

 Den vanligste plagen i brystryggområdet. Ofte forårsaket av muskulære spenninger, triggerpunkter

 Ribbeinsløsning

 Akutt smerte

 Kostokondritt

 Gå til full artikkel → 

 Betennelse i bruskovergangen mellom ribbein og brystbein. Gir smerter på fremsiden av brystkassen som

 4-8% av befolkningen (AAPMR, 2024)

 Flat rygg (Hypokyfose)

 Osteoporose og brudd

Beskriv årsaker - fra vanligst til sjeldnest for Hodepine og svimmelhet.

Årsaker - fra vanligst til sjeldnest

 1. Vestibular migrene

 Vestibular migrene er den hyppigste årsaken til episodisk vertigo hos voksne, med en befolkningsprevalens på 0,9-2,7% (Formeister 2018). Blant migrenepasienter har 10,3% vestibular migrene.

 Det uvanlige med denne tilstanden er at hodepine og svimmelhet ofte ikke opptrer samtidig . Gjennomsnittlig går det 8 år fra første migrene til vestibulære symptomer utvikles.

 Svimmelhetsepisoder som varer fra minutter til timer

 Lys- og lydfølsomhet under anfall

 Forverring ved hodebevegelser

 Ofte reisesyke gjennom hele livet

 Kvinner rammes 3-5 ganger oftere enn menn

 NB: Vestibular migrene er sterkt underdiagnostisert. Kun 10-20% av pasientene får korrekt diagnose.

 2. Cervikogen svimmelhet (nakke-relatert)

 Cervikogen dysekvilibrium rammer 40% av cervikalgi-pasienter (Vural 2021). Av disse var 59,7% relatert til myofascialt smertesyndrom (muskelspenninger med triggerpunkter ). Dette overlapper ofte med nakkehodepine .

 Nakken inneholder ekstremt mange proprioseptorer (stillingsfølere) - spesielt i de små musklene overst mot hodeskallen. Når disse sender feil signaler, oppstår en konflikt mellom det nakken "forteller" hjernen og det balanseorganet i året registrerer.

 Svimmelhet ved hodebevegelser

 Nakkesmerter eller stivhet

 Ofte utløst av stillinger eller aktiviteter

 SCM-triggerpunkter kan gi både hodepine og svimmelhet

 3. BPPV med sekundær hodepine

 Godartet posisjonsbetinget vertigo (BPPV) er den vanligste enkeltårsaken til vertigo generelt - ansvarlig for ca. halvparten av alle vestibulære konsultasjoner.

 34,8% av BPPV-pasienter rapporterer også hodepine. Migrenepasienter har dobbelt så høy risiko for å utvikle BPPV sammenlignet med normalbefolkningen.

 4. Spenningshodepine med svimmelhet

 Spenningshodepine er den vanligste hodepinetypen generelt.

Forklar behandling for Kronisk Ryggsmerte.

Behandling

 WHOs retningslinje fra 2023 for ikke-kirurgisk behandling av kronisk ryggsmerte gir tydelige anbefalinger. Det viktigste budskapet er at enkelttiltak alene sjelden er tilstrekkelig - det er kombinasjonen av flere tilnærminger som gir best resultat.

 Anbefalt av WHO (2023)

 Hva anbefales?

 Strukturerte treningsprogrammer: Trening har den sterkeste evidensen for kronisk ryggsmerte (WHO, 2023)

 Spinal manipulasjon: WHO anbefaler manuell behandling som del av behandlingstilbudet (WHO, 2023)

 Smerteutdanning (PNE): Forståelse av smertemekanismer kan redusere smerte og kinesiofobi (MDPI, 2024)

 Kognitiv atferdsterapi: Kan adressere frykt-unngåelse og katastrofisering

 Tverrfaglig rehabilitering: Kombinasjon av fysisk trening, psykologisk støtte og utdanning

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Beveg deg daglig

 Trening er det tiltaket med sterkest evidens for kronisk ryggsmerte. Det trenger ikke være avansert
 Gåturer: 30 minutter daglig i moderat tempo

 Styrketrening: Core-øvelser, knebøy, planke - 2-3 ganger i uken

 Bevegelighet: Hoftefleksortøying, thorakal mobilitet, yoga eller tai chi

 Den beste øvelsen er den du faktisk gjennomfører.

 Prioriter søvn

 Dårlig søvn og smerte forsterker hverandre. Noen enkle grep
 Faste leggetider

 Unngå skjerm en time før sengetid

 Kjølig soverom (16-18 grader)

 Sideleie med pute mellom knærne kan avlaste korsryggen

 Håndter stress

 Kronisk stress kan holde nervesystemet i alarmberedskap. Pusteøvelser, turer i naturen, eller noe så enkelt som å tilbringe tid med mennesker du liker, kan bidra til å roe systemet ned.

Describe treatment options for Meniere's Disease.

Treatment

 

 There is no cure for Meniere's disease. The goal of treatment is to reduce attack frequency, relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.

 Conservative Treatment and Lifestyle

 
 Salt Reduction

 A stable, low salt intake (<1500-2000 mg sodium daily) is often recommended as first-line treatment. The theory is that this can stabilize the fluid balance in the inner ear. The Cochrane review from 2018 found no randomized studies supporting this, but many patients report improvement.

 

 Medical Treatment

 
 Betahistine (Betaserc)

 The most commonly used medication in Europe. The BEMED study (2016) found no significant difference between betahistine and placebo, but the medication is well tolerated and is often tried for 3-6 months.

 

 Vestibular Rehabilitation

 AAO-HNS recommends vestibular rehabilitation for patients with chronic unsteadiness between attacks. A meta-analysis from 2023 found moderate effect on quality of life.

 
 Important About Vestibular Rehabilitation

 Vestibular rehabilitation is not recommended during acute attacks - it is well-documented when vertigo episodes are under control.

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Contribute?

 Chiropractors cannot treat the fluid accumulation in the inner ear itself. But many people with Meniere's disease develop secondary problems that I can help with:

 
 Neck and shoulder tension: Chronic stress and abnormal head position during attacks often lead to muscle tightness, which can cause cervicogenic di...

Describe symptoms for Discogenic Pain.

Symptoms

 Characteristics of Discogenic Pain
 Location: Deep, central pain in the middle of the low back

 Character: Dull, aching - not sharp or electric

 Possible radiation: Diffuse to buttock or thigh, but without sharp nerve pattern

 Key finding: Poor sitting tolerance - often under 30 minutes

 What Worsens and Relieves?

 Worsened by: Prolonged sitting, forward bending, coughing, sneezing, lifting

 Relieved by: Lying down, standing up, moving around, changing position regularly

 What You DON'T Have with Pure Discogenic Pain

 With pure discogenic pain, I see no signs of nerve root involvement: no numbness, no tingling, no muscle weakness, normal reflexes, and negative straight leg raise test. If you have such symptoms, it may point toward herniation with nerve compression - a different condition requiring a different approach.

Describe The Most Important Examination Finding in the context of Costochondritis and Chest Pain.

Sharp, stabbing or aching pain along the breastbone, often on one side

 Worsening with deep breathing, coughing and sneezing

 Increased pain with movement of the upper body or arms

 Local tenderness that can be reproduced by pressing on the cartilage connections

 Radiation along the ribs to the back, or to arms and shoulders

 
 

 Pain can vary from mild to intense. Many describe a feeling that "something is stuck" in the chest.
 Symptoms can last from a few weeks to several months without treatment.

 

 
 
 
 5
 Diagnostics

 

 Costochondritis is a clinical diagnosis - there is no blood test or imaging that
 confirms the condition. The diagnosis is made based on medical history and physical examination.

 
 The Most Important Examination Finding

 Pain can be reproduced by pressing on the affected cartilage connections. This is called
 reproducible tenderness and is characteristic of the condition.
 

 

 When is Imaging Necessary?

 X-ray and MRI are rarely indicated for typical costochondritis. Imaging may be relevant to rule out other
 causes with atypical symptoms, prolonged course, or suspected underlying disease.

 
 Validated Clinical Tool

 Chest Wall Syndrome Clinical Prediction Rule (Gencer et al., BMC Family Practice, 2012) uses six
 factors to identify chest wall syndrome with 88.6% specificity: localized muscle tension, stabbing pain
 character, reproducible pain on palpation, absence of cough, pain that is not retrosternal or pressing,
 and no known coronary disease.

Aktiviteter som Øker risikoen

 
 Bakkeloping - særlig oppover

 Intervalltrening - høye hastighetskrav

 Sykling - særlig med lav sadelhyde

 Yoga og pilates - mye hamstringtoying

 Symptomer

 

 Typiske symptomer

 
 Lokalisert smerte ved sitteknuten - der "rumpå moter læret"

 Vondt å sitte - særlig på harde flater

 Stivhet om morgenen - typisk for seneproblemer

 Smerte ved hamstringtoying

 

 Smerteforverring ved:

 
 Sitte på harde stoler

 Bilkjoring - særlig lange turer

 Lope - verst ved bakker og intervaller

 Toye hamstrings

 Lunges og dyp kneboying

 Reise seg fra sittende

 Nedover baksiden av læret (kan ligne isjias)

 Opp i setet

S: 32 år, gravid uke 28, para 2. Gradvis økende smerter i symfysen og venstre SI-ledd siste 4 uker. Verst ved gange, trappegang og snuing i sengen. VAS 7/10 ved aktivitet. Vanskelig å stå på ett ben. Sover dårlig. Ingen urinveissymptomer.

O: Posisjonering: Sideleie gjennom hele undersøkelse. Observasjon: Antalgisk gange, svangerskapslordose. ASLR: Positiv bilateralt. P4-test: Positiv venstre. Palpasjon: Øm symfyse og venstre SI-ledd. Ingen nevrologiske funn.

A: Bekkenleddsmerter i svangerskap/symfysedysfunksjon (O26.89). Ingen obstetriske bekymringer identifisert.

P: Behandling: Forsiktig mobilisering SI-ledd bilat (grad 1-2), PIR adduktorer og psoas bilat, Trp gluteus medius bilat. Kun sideleie-teknikker, ingen HVLA til bekken/lumbal. Tilpasset bekkenbelteunderstøttelse. Øvelser: Bekkentilt, forsiktig hoftemobilitet, bekkenbunn. Sovepute mellom knærne. Aktivitetstilpasning. Vurdere sykemelding ved behov. Ukentlig oppfølging gjennom svangerskapet.

Assess red flags: 48-year-old male with acute torticollis after turning suddenly in car. Left-sided neck pain, reduced left rotation. Full arm strength. Normal reflexes. No headache. No dizziness. No visual disturbances.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Systematic red flag screening:

✗ Vascular: No headache, no dizziness, no visual disturbances, no Horner signs → EXCLUDED
✗ Fracture: Not high-energy trauma (car turning ≠ collision), no focal percussion tenderness → EXCLUDED
✗ Infection: No fever, no night sweats, no immunosuppression → EXCLUDED
✗ Malignancy: Under 50, no weight loss, no cancer history → EXCLUDED
✗ Myelopathy: Full bilateral strength, normal reflexes, normal gait → EXCLUDED
✗ Radiculopathy: No arm radiation, normal sensation → EXCLUDED

Clinical picture: Acute mechanical torticollis.

Safe to treat with gentle mobilization, heat, NSAID if needed. Expected improvement 3-7 days.

Beskriv Kirurgi i kontekst av Biceps tendinopati: Alt du trenger å vite.

PRP (Platelet-Rich Plasma)

 Injeksjon av blodplater fra pasientens eget blod. Evidensen er fortsatt begrenset, men noen studier viser lovende resultater for seneproblemer.

 

 Kirurgi

 Kirurgi vurderes kun når konservativ behandling over 3-6 måneder ikke gir tilfredsstillende bedring. Alternativer inkluderer:

 
 Tenotomi: Senen kuttes og får trekke seg ned (enklere, raskere rehabilitering)

 Tenodese: Senen festes på nytt til overarmsbeinet (bevarer styrke og kontur)

 

 
 Prognose etter kirurgi

 Bade tenotomi og tenodese gir gode resultater hos de fleste. Valget avhenger av alder, aktivitetsniva og kosmetiske preferanser. Tenodese foretrekkes ofte hos yngre, aktive pasienter.

Treatment

 

 What does the research say?

 EULAR (European League Against Rheumatism) published revised guidelines in 2017. Exercise is the
 a key treatment approach with a strong recommendation. A network meta-analysis from 2024 (51 studies,
 2873 patients) showed that water exercise is well-documented short-term, while strength training is best
 long-term.

 
 Treatment options

 
 Exercise (strong recommendation): Water exercise well-documented short-term,
 strength training best long-term. 51 studies with 2873 patients document the effect.

 Massage therapy (5+ weeks): Shows moderate effect for pain, anxiety and depression.
 Myofascial release (soft tissue treatment) had the most suitable effect.

 Manual treatment/chiropractic: EULAR guidelines give a "strong against"
 recommendation for chiropractic for fibromyalgia. A systematic review (Ernst, 2009) concluded
 "insufficient evidence".

 
 

 What can the chiropractor do?

 Given the limited evidence, a consultation is primarily about:

 
 Thorough examination - ruling out other causes of chest pain

 Soft tissue treatment - gentle treatment of muscle tightness, not aggressive
 manipulation

 Exercise guidance - help getting started with adapted exercise

 Pain management - explanation of central sensitization, sleep hygiene, stress
 management

 Chiropractic is not a first-line treatment for fibromyalgia based on current research. Exercise and
 cognitive therapy have far better e...

Patient asks: "What is the difference between impingement and rotator cuff injury?"

Shoulder impingement describes pain during movement, often linked to irritation in the subacromial space. Rotator cuff injury is a specific tendon/muscle injury. They often overlap - over 80% with impingement have concurrent rotator cuff tendinopathy (Seitz et al. 2011). Treatment is largely the same: exercises and gradual progressive training.

Describe causes and risk factors for Plantar Fasciopathy.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Research has identified several risk factors, ranked by how strongly they affect the chance of developing
 the condition
 Limited ankle mobility

 23x increased risk with zero degrees dorsiflexion or less (Riddle et al., JBJS 2003)

 Obesity (BMI > 30)

 5-6x increased risk compared to normal weight

 Occupations with lots of standing

 4x increased risk when standing most of the workday

 Foot structure

 Both flat foot and high arch can increase load on the plantar fascia

 Sudden increase in activity - like starting to run after a long break, or increasing
 training volume too quickly - is a classic triggering factor. This type of overload can also lead to stress fractures in the foot.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hvor lenge varer svimmelhet etter hjernerystelse?

 For de fleste går svimmelheten over i løpet av dager til noen uker. Med vestibular rehabilitering er de fleste betydelig bedre innen 4-8 uker. Rundt 10-15% får vedvarende plager utover 3 måneder, og noen kan utvikle PPPD (kronisk svimmelhet).

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor behandle plager etter hjernerystelse?

 Ja, kiropraktorer med kompetanse på vestibular rehabilitering kan gi effektiv behandling. Kombinasjonen av vestibular rehabilitering og nakkebehandling har sterk forskningsstotte.

 

 
 Bør jeg unnga aktivitet hvis jeg er svimmel etter hjernerystelse?

 Nei, langvarig inaktivitet kan faktisk forsinke bedringen. Etter 24-48 timers relativ hvile bør du gradvis gjenoppta aktivitet tilpasset symptomene.

 

 
 Trenger jeg MR eller CT?

 Ved typisk hjernerystelse og PCS viser bildediagnostikk normale funn - skaden er funksjonell, ikke strukturell. MR/CT er indisert ved røde flagg-symptomer for å utelukke blodning eller strukturskade.

How is Vestibular Neuritis diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Vestibular neuritis is primarily a clinical diagnosis. The most important thing is to distinguish it from stroke in the cerebellum or brainstem, which can cause very similar symptoms. Approximately 25% of patients with acute vestibular syndrome may have central nervous system causes.

 The HINTS Examination

 HINTS (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew) is a three-step eye examination that, in cases of acute dizziness, has proven more sensitive than MRI for detecting stroke in the first 24-48 hours. Performed by trained clinicians, HINTS is 96.5% sensitive and 84-96% specific.

 
 Head Impulse Test

 Rapid passive head rotation while the patient focuses. In vestibular neuritis, the gaze will "slip" and must be corrected.

 

 
 Nystagmus

 In vestibular neuritis, nystagmus is unidirectional - the eyes beat the same direction regardless of gaze direction.

 

 
 Test of Skew

 Alternating covering of the eyes. Vertical readjustment indicates brainstem lesion.

Describe Three Main Categories of Dizziness for Types of Dizziness: How to Tell the Difference Between Different Forms.

Three Main Categories of Dizziness

 

 Before we get into specific diagnoses, it's helpful to understand the three main types of dizziness:

 
 Vertigo - Room Spinning

 With vertigo, you experience that you or your surroundings are rotating. There's a clear sensation of movement even when you're sitting still. This is almost always caused by problems in the balance organ in the inner ear.

 
 Typical description: "The room is spinning", "I'm whirling around"

 Common causes: BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's disease

 Often accompanied by: Nausea, vomiting, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements)

 
 

 
 Unsteadiness - Rocking or Swaying Sensation

 With unsteadiness, you feel off-balance without the room spinning. It can be described as standing on a boat deck or walking on an unstable surface.

 
 Typical description: "Like being on a boat", "I feel unstable"

 Common causes: Cervicogenic dizziness, PPPD, vestibular hypofunction

 Often accompanied by: Neck pain, anxiety, worsening in crowds

 
 

 
 Lightheadedness - Foggy Head

 With lightheadedness, you feel "light-headed", distant, or like you're about to faint. There's no clear sensation of movement.

 
 Typical description: "Foggy", "almost like I'm going to faint"

 Common causes: Orthostatic hypotension, anemia, medications, anxiety

 Often accompanied by: Palpitations, sweating, vision darkening when standing up

Describe symptoms for Shoulder Impingement.

Symptoms

 The typical symptoms of shoulder impingement are easily recognizable and differ from other shoulder conditions
 Painful arc

 The most characteristic symptom: Pain that occurs when lifting the arm out to the side, typically between 60-120 degrees . Below and above this range, movement is often pain-free. The pain occurs because the structures in the subacromial space are compressed most in this range.

 Other common symptoms

 Night pain: Pain when lying on the affected shoulder

 Pain with overhead movements: Lifting objects overhead, washing hair

 Feeling of weakness: Difficulty holding heavy objects away from the body

 Stiffness: Gradually reduced mobility with long-standing symptoms

 Crepitus: Grinding or clicking during movement

 Differs from frozen shoulder

 With impingement, it is primarily active movement that is painful, while passive range of motion is often preserved. With frozen shoulder , both active and passive range of motion are reduced. This is an important clinical distinction.

 Idiopathic (50-83%)

 Female sex

 Hypertension and diabetes

 Vitamin D deficiency

 Osteoporosis

Describe symptoms and signs of Dizzy When Lying Down? What You Need to Know About BPPV.

Symptoms

 

 The classic symptom is brief, intense rotational vertigo triggered by specific head movements:

 
 Typical triggers

 
 Lying down in bed

 Turning over in bed (especially to one side)

 Tilting the head back (e.g., looking up into a cupboard)

 Rising quickly from a lying position

 
 

 
 Typical course

 
 Delay: 5-10 seconds after the head movement before the dizziness starts

 Duration: Typically under 60 seconds - rarely over one minute

 Additional symptoms: Nausea is common, vomiting occurs with severe episodes

 After-effect: Mild lightheadedness and unsteadiness for minutes to hours afterward

 
 

 
 This is NOT typical for BPPV

 The following symptoms suggest a different cause and require further investigation:

 
 Hearing loss or tinnitus

 Pressure or fullness in the ear

 Persistent dizziness (not just with head movements)

 Neurological symptoms such as double vision, numbness, or paralysis

Describe Types of Sports Injuries for Sports Injuries - Complete Guide.

Types of Sports Injuries

 

 Acute vs. Overuse Injuries

 Sports injuries fall into two main categories, each requiring different treatment approaches:

 
 Acute Injuries

 Result from a single traumatic event - a fall, collision, or sudden movement. Examples include ankle sprains, muscle tears, and ligament ruptures. These typically cause immediate pain and swelling.

 

 
 Overuse Injuries

 Develop gradually from repetitive stress over time. Examples include tendinopathies (Achilles, patellar), stress fractures, and shin splints. Pain often starts mild and worsens if training continues unchanged.

 

 Common Sports Injuries

 
 Muscle strains: Tears in muscle fibers, often in hamstrings, quads, or calves

 Ligament sprains: Stretching or tearing of ligaments, commonly ankle or knee

 Tendinopathies: Degeneration of tendons from repetitive loading

 Stress fractures: Small cracks in bone from cumulative overload

 Joint injuries: Cartilage damage, labral tears, meniscus injuries

Explain treatment for Pregnant with Back Pain? How a Chiropractor Can Help.

Treatment

 What can the chiropractor do?

 Chiropractic treatment during pregnancy is safe when performed with adapted techniques. A systematic
 review from Cochrane found moderate evidence that manual treatment can reduce pain and improve function
 in pregnant women.

 A study by Peterson et al. (2014) found that 52% of pregnant women reported improvement after
 just one week of chiropractic treatment.

 Typical Treatment Methods

 Gentle joint mobilization of pelvis and lower back

 Soft tissue treatment of tight muscles

 Guidance in exercises and posture

 Pregnancy pillows or side-lying positions to avoid pressure on the abdomen

 What can you do yourself?

 Stabilizing exercises: Norwegian research shows that 68% had minimal or no pain
 after exercise treatment

 Stay active: Moderate activity like swimming and walking is often better than rest

 Pillow between knees: Relieves the pelvis when you sleep on your side

 Avoid asymmetric loads: Sit down when putting on pants

 Pelvic belt: Can provide support for pelvic girdle pain

 Treatment Course

 Research shows that many experience improvement relatively quickly. One study reported that patients
 needed an average of 1.8 treatments before noticing clear improvement.

 Many pregnant women benefit from treatment every 2-4 weeks throughout pregnancy, with more frequent
 visits as needed.

Vurder røde flagg for Vondt i Hoften? - Komplett guide.

Akutt selvhjelp: Hva du kan gjøre nå

 

 Mens du venter på behandling, er det viktig å ikke irritere vevet unoedig. Her er "brannslukkingstiltakene" jeg anbefaler:

 
 
 1
 Slik bør du sove

 

 
 Nattsmerter er sværtvanlig ved hoftesmerter, særlig ved seneproblemer på utsiden (GTPS). Når du ligger på siden, komprimeres senene mot benet - som å klemme en sene mellom to harde flater.

 
 Unngå å ligge på den vonde siden: Dette Økerkompresjonen på senene.

 Bruk pute mellom knærne: Hvis du ligger på den friske siden, holder en tykk pute fra kne til ankel hoften noeytral.

 Ligge på ryggen: Ofte den beste stillingen. Eventuelt med en pute under knærne.

 
 

 

 
 
 2
 Slik bør du sitte og stå

 

 
 
 Ikke sitt med bena i kryss: Dette strekker senene på utsiden av hoften.

 Unngå å "henge" på hoften: Når du står, fordel vekten likt på begge ben.

 Ved lyskesmerter: Senk stolen litt eller vipp setet forover for å Åpne hoftevinkelen.

Describe symptoms for Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant.

Symptoms

 Characteristic Presentation
 Dizziness When Bending Forward and Backward

 Typical dizziness when tilting the head backward (looking up at shelves) or forward (picking something up from the floor). This differs from posterior canal BPPV, which is primarily triggered by lying down.

 Shorter Duration

 Dizziness episodes often last less than 15 seconds, somewhat shorter than posterior canal BPPV (15-45 seconds).

 Often Milder Symptoms

 Symptom intensity may be lower than with other BPPV variants.

 Bilateral Triggering

 Can be triggered from both sides during the Dix-Hallpike test.

Hva er prognosen for Krystallsyke (BPPV)?

Prognose

 

 BPPV er en godartet tilstand med svært god prognose. Reposisjonsmanvrer gir umiddelbar bedring hos de fleste.

 Restsvimmelhet etter behandling

 31-61% av pasientene rapporterer vedvarende lett svimmelhet eller ustohet etter vellykket behandling, selv om nystagmus og posisjonsell vertigo er borte. Denne restsvimmelheten varer vanligvis i median 10 dager og forsvinner som regel innen 3 måneder. Hos noen kan dette utvikle seg til PPPD (vedvarende postural-perseptuell svimmelhet).

 Tilbakefall er vanlig

 
 Ca. 15-23% opplever tilbakefall innen første Ør

 5-Ørs tilbakefallsrate er rundt 40%

 Opp til 50% kan oppleve ny episode innen 5 Ør

 

 Forebygging av tilbakefall

 D-vitamintilskudd hos pasienter med påvist mangel kan redusere risikoen for nye episoder. En meta-analyse viste signifikant reduksjon i tilbakefallsrate (relativ risiko 0,37).

 Self-massage technique

 
 Find the tender point by palpating the muscles

 Gently stretch the muscle afterward

 Repeat 2-3 times daily

 Ergonomics: Correct work position at computer

 Warm up: Before physical activity involving arms

 Stress management: Stress increases muscle tension

Provide a structured clinical overview of SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction.

What is the SI Joint?: The SI joint is a unique joint - part synovial joint (movable), part fibrous joint (stable). Normal
 movement is very limited: only 2-4 mm rotation and 1-2 mm gliding. Nevertheless, these minimal movements
 are essential for normal walking function and for absorbing shock.

Pelvic Locking vs. Pelvic Loosening: The terms "pelvic locking" and "pelvic loosening" describe two completely different conditions that
 require different treatment approaches
Causes and Risk Factors: Pain from the SI joint can have both intra-articular (inside the joint) and extra-articular (around the
 joint) causes. Here are the most common, ranked from most to least frequent
Symptoms - What SI Joint Pain Feels Like: The pain is usually located right over the SI joint - slightly to the side from the midline, just below
 the hip crest. Most experience one-sided pain localized to the area around or just below
 the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS). In 94% of cases, the patient can point to the pain within 10 cm
 below and 3 cm lateral to the PSIS.

Diagnosis - How is the Diagnosis Made?: SI joint problems cannot be seen on X-ray or MRI. The diagnosis is made primarily clinically through pain
 location, provocation tests, and palpation. Individual tests have limited value - therefore a
 cluster of provocation tests is used. Three or more positive tests give 94% sensitivity
 and 78% specificity.

Treatment: Conservative treatment is the first choice. A recent systematic review by Trager et al. (JMMT, 2024) with
 16 RCTs and 776 patients found significant improvement in function. Visser et al. (2013) compared three
 approaches
Red Flags - When You Should See a Doctor: Read more about red flags for back pain .

Prognosis - What to Expect?: Up to 95% of patients respond well to conservative treatment with significant pain
 reduction within 1-3 months. Most improve significantly within the first few weeks.

Symptoms of True Sciatica

 

 Classic symptoms include pain from the lower back/buttock, down the back of the thigh, below the knee,
 potentially to the foot and toes. The pain pattern depends on which nerve root is affected:

 
 L4 root

 
 Pain to the front of the thigh and inner calf

 Weakened knee extension

 
 

 
 L5 root (L4-L5 herniation)

 
 Pain to the outer calf and top of the foot

 Weakened toe dorsiflexion

 
 

 
 S1 root (L5-S1 herniation)

 
 Pain to the back of the calf and outer foot

 Weakened toe plantar flexion, reduced Achilles reflex

 
 

 Pain quality and provocation

 
 Pain quality: Sharp, burning, electric. Often described as "current" through the leg.
 

 Worsening: Coughing, sneezing, straining, sitting, forward bending typically
 increases pain.

 Relief: Lying on your back with bent knees, gentle movement.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Osteitis Pubis - Chiropractor in Oslo.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I exercise with osteitis pubis?

 Yes, but you should modify your training. Avoid activities that provoke pain
 (kicking, jumping, rapid direction changes). Swimming, cycling and upper body strength training can
 often be continued. Gradual increase in loading under guidance is key to successful rehabilitation.
 

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 With structured rehabilitation, most return to full activity within 3-6 months. Without active treatment, symptoms can last 8-12 months or longer.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor help with osteitis pubis?

 Yes. Chiropractors can offer manual treatment of pelvic and hip joints, soft tissue treatment and individually tailored exercise programs. Many patients report good results from multimodal chiropractic treatment combined with rehabilitation exercises.

 The prognosis for cervical radiculopathy is generally good. Most improve significantly with
 conservative treatment, and only a minority need surgery.

 First improvement

 Acute phase

Red flags for Back, Hip or Sciatica??

A Common and Complex Picture

 Up to 30% of patients with hip osteoarthritis have simultaneous
 significant spinal disease. This is called "hip-spine syndrome" and complicates both
 diagnosis and treatment.

 Why Does This Occur?

 Biomechanical coupling: A stiff hip increases load on the back

 Compensatory patterns: Altered gait affects the entire kinetic
 chain

 Common risk factors: Age, overweight, physical inactivity

 Sensitization: Chronic pain can make the entire region
 hypersensitive

 Treatment Implications
 When both back and hip are involved, both must be addressed to achieve improvement. A
 hip replacement, for example, cannot solve a simultaneous back problem, and vice
 versa.

Differential diagnoses for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS): Numb Arm and Tingling?

1. Neurogenic TOS (nTOS)

 90-97% of cases 

 By far the most common form. The nerves in the brachial plexus (the nerve network supplying the arm)
 become compressed.

 Typical symptoms
 Pain in neck, shoulder and arm

 Numbness and tingling in fingers (often 4th and 5th finger)

 Weakness in hand/grip strength

 Symptoms worsen with overhead work

 "Numb arm" at night

2. Venous TOS (vTOS)

 2-3% of cases 

 Compression of the subclavian vein (the vein that carries blood from the arm).

 Typical symptoms
 Swelling in arm and hand

 Bluish discoloration (cyanosis)

 Heaviness sensation in the arm

 Visible dilated veins on shoulder/chest

 Can lead to blood clot (Paget-Schroetter syndrome)

3. Arterial TOS (aTOS)

 1% of cases 

 Compression of the subclavian artery (the artery that supplies blood to the arm). Rare but
 potentially serious.

 Typical symptoms
 Cold, pale arm/hand

 Pain with activity (claudication)

 Weak or absent pulse in the wrist

 Can lead to embolism or aneurysm

Explain prognosis - what happens? for Headache After Whiplash.

Prognosis - What happens?

 The first 3 months are crucial

 Research shows that improvement mainly occurs during the first 3 months after the injury. After this,
 the improvement curve flattens dramatically. A study found that 86% of those who were still symptomatic
 at 3 months remained symptomatic after 2 years.

 Three typical courses (Sterling et al., JOSPT 2016)

 ~50% 
 Mild course: Full recovery 

 ~30% 
 Moderate course: Persistent moderate symptoms 

 ~20% 
 Severe course: Chronic disability 

 Risk factors for poor outcome

 High initial pain intensity, high functional disability from the start, cold sensitivity, pain
 catastrophizing and post-traumatic stress symptoms increase the risk of chronicity. Low expectations of
 improvement is a strong negative prognostic factor.

 Relapse is common

 Even among those who recover, many experience relapse. Long-term studies show that only about 35% are
 fully recovered after 5 years. This underscores the importance of learning self-management strategies.

Describe When You Don't Breathe With Your Belly for Breathing, Stress and Back.

When You Don't Breathe With Your Belly

 

 Dysfunctional Breathing Is More Common Than You Think

 Approximately 6-10% of the general population has dysfunctional breathing (Thomas et
 al., 2005; Boulding et al., 2016). Among asthma patients, this rises to 29-47%.

 Dysfunctional breathing means you use the wrong muscles. Instead of letting the diaphragm do the work,
 the body recruits accessory muscles in the neck and shoulders - muscles that are actually meant for
 short-term effort.

 
 The Vicious Cycle

 
 Accessory muscles overworked

 →
 Neck and shoulder pain

 →
 Stress response increases

 →
 Breathing becomes more shallow

 

 

 
 Signs That You're Breathing Wrong

 
 Shoulders rise during inhalation (instead of the belly expanding)

 Feeling of never getting enough air, even at rest

 Tension in neck and shoulders

 Frequent sighing or yawning

 Fatigue that isn't explained by lack of sleep

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Kan dårlig holdning virkelig påvirke pusten?

 Ja. Studier viser at hyperkyfose reduserer diafragmabevegelse med opptil 35% og lungekapasitet med 0,25-0,81 liter. Dette er målbare, fysiologiske endringer.

 

 
 Hjelper det å "rette seg opp" bevisst?

 På kort sikt ja, men aktiv muskelbruk er slitsomt. Målet er å forbedre thorakal bevegelighet slik at en god holdning krever mindre anstrengelse. Trening og mobilisering er mer effektivt enn bare å "tenke på å sitte rett".

 

 
 Kan pusteØvelser virkelig redusere stress?

 Forskning viser moderat effekt (effektstørrelse 0,35). Forlenget utpust aktiverer det parasympatiske nervesystemet og kan senke kortisolnivåer. Effekten kommer etter noen dagers regelmessig Øving.

 

 
 Hvor lenge må jeg gjøre Øvelser får det hjelper?

 De fleste studier viser effekt etter 4-8 uker med regelmessig trening (2-3 Økter per uke). PusteØvelser kan gi umiddelbar avspenningseffekt, men varige endringer krever tid.

 

 
 Er det farlig å ha krum rygg?

 Ikke nødvendigvis. Mange lever fint med varierende grad av kyfose. Problemet oppstar når stivheten begrenser funksjon eller gir plager. En fleksibel kyfose er mindre problematisk enn en rigid en.

 Vanligvis ikke ved typiske holdningsplager. Klinisk undersøkelse gir ofte tilstrekkelig informasjon. Bildediagnostikk kan våre aktuelt ved mistanke om strukturelle Årsaker som Scheuermanns sykdom eller kompresjonsbrudd.

Describe Imaging is rarely necessary in the context of Pain Between Shoulder Blades.

Imaging is rarely necessary

 MRI and X-ray often show age-related changes - such as disc degeneration or facet joint arthritis - in
 people without pain. A study found that 89% of people between 60 and 69 years have facet joint arthritis
 on MRI without having symptoms (Wood and colleagues).

 The images can therefore be misleading. Clinical examination often provides more relevant
 information than what the images can tell.

 Imaging is indicated when there is suspicion of serious pathology, after trauma, or with neurological
 deficits that do not improve.

Describe diagnosis for SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

Diagnosis

 Diagnosing SLAP lesion is challenging and often requires a combination of clinical findings and
 imaging.

 Clinical tests

 Several tests have been described, but none have high enough accuracy alone
 O'Brien's test (Active compression): Most used, but moderate sensitivity

 Biceps load test: Positive with external rotation against resistance

 Anterior slide test 

 Crank test 

 Limitations of tests

 A meta-analysis showed that even the best clinical tests have limited accuracy. Combination of
 several positive tests increases the probability, but the diagnosis can rarely be made clinically
 alone.

 Imaging

 MR arthrography (gold standard)

 MRI with contrast injected into the joint. Provides the best visualization of the labrum and can
 distinguish between different types of SLAP lesions. Sensitivity around 80-90%.

 Regular MRI

 Can detect SLAP lesions, but has lower sensitivity than MR arthrography. Useful for looking for
 concomitant pathology (rotator cuff, etc.).

 Important caveats

 Even MR arthrography has false-positive findings

 SLAP changes are common in asymptomatic individuals

 MRI findings must always be correlated with clinical findings

 Age over 40: Type I changes are often normal findings

Beskriv diagnostikk for SLAP.

Diagnostikk

 Diagnosen SLAP-lesjon er utfordrende og krever ofte en kombinasjon av kliniske funn og bildediagnostikk.

 Kliniske tester

 Flere tester er beskrevet, men ingen har høy nok noyaktighet alene
 O'Brien's test (Active compression): Mest brukte, men moderat sensitivitet

 Biceps load test: Positiv ved utadrotasjon mot motstand

 Anterior slide test 

 Crank test 

 Testenes begrensninger

 En metaanalyse viste at selv de beste kliniske testene har begrenset noyaktighet. Kombinasjon av flere positive tester økersannsynligheten, men diagnosen kan sjelden stilles klinisk alene.

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR artrografi (gullstandard)

 MR med kontrast injisert i leddet. Gir best visualisering av labrum og kan skille mellom ulike typer SLAP-lesjoner. Sensitivitet rundt 80-90%.

 Vanlig MR

 Kan påvirke SLAP-lesjoner, men har lavere sensitivitet enn MR artrografi. Nyttig for å se etter samtidig patologi (rotatormansjett, etc.).

 Viktige forbehold

 Selv MR artrografi har falsk-positive funn

 SLAP-forandringer er vanlige hos asymptomatiske

 MR-funn må alltid korreleres med klinikken

 Alder over 40 år: Type I-forandringer er ofte normalfunn

Acute Treatment - PRICE Principle

 For acute injuries, rapid and correct first aid is crucial for optimal healing
 P - Protection: Avoid activities that provoke pain

 R - Rest: Relative rest - not complete immobilization

Describe Forward Head Posture (FHP) for TMD and Neck Pain: Why Jaw and Neck Are Connected.

Forward Head Posture (FHP)

 

 One of the most important connections between neck and jaw is posture - specifically what's called forward head posture (FHP). Normally, the ear should be in line with the shoulder when viewed from the side. With FHP, the head is shifted forward.

 
 
 60-66%
 of office workers have FHP
 

 
 60%
 increased neck load
 

 
 4.5 kg
 extra per 2.5 cm forward
 

 

 Consequences for the Neck

 
 For every 2.5 cm the head moves forward, the load on the neck increases by about 4.5 kg

 With typical FHP, the load can increase by 60% or more

 Neck muscles must work constantly to hold the head up

 Upper cervical vertebrae compress backward (extension)

 

 Consequences for the Jaw

 
 The lower jaw is pulled back and down

 Jaw muscles activate compensatorily to keep the mouth closed

 The jaw joint is loaded asymmetrically

 Increased risk of teeth grinding (bruxism)

 

 
 Vicious Cycle

 FHP leads to increased neck load, neck muscles tighten, suboccipital muscles compress C1-C2, referred pain to jaw via TCC, jaw muscles tighten in response, increased load on jaw joint, more pain, more muscle tightness, worse posture. The cycle must be broken at multiple points.

Exercise 3: Towel Curls

 

 A classic exercise that strengthens the flexor muscles under the foot. This exercise is particularly useful for those with plantar fasciitis.

 
 How to Perform Towel Curls

 
 Starting position: Sit with your foot on a towel on the floor

 Movement: Use your toes to pull the towel toward you

 Focus: Grip with all toes, including the big toe

 Repetitions: Pull in the entire towel, 2-3 times

 Variation: Pick up marbles or small objects with your toes

 
 

 
 Marble Variation

 Place 10-20 marbles (or other small objects) on the floor and pick them up one by one with your toes. This trains both grip and precision. A good variation to keep training interesting.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Numbness in Fingers: Is It the Neck or the Hand?.

Two Common Causes of Numb Fingers: When you experience numbness in your fingers, two main causes must be considered
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome - When the Nerve is Compressed in the Wrist: Carpal tunnel syndrome causes numbness and tingling in the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and half of the ring finger - the median nerve's distribution area. The little finger is usually unaffected.

Cervical Radiculopathy - When the Nerve is Compressed in the Neck: Symptoms of cervical radiculopathy depend on which nerve root is affected
How to Distinguish Between the Conditions: In some cases, the patient actually has both conditions simultaneously. This is called "double crush syndrome" , where irritation of the nerve at one level makes it more vulnerable to effects elsewhere.

Treatment: Conservative treatment is first choice for mild to moderate symptoms

Assess red flags: 50-year-old male with bilateral leg heaviness after 10 km run. Bilateral foot numbness that resolved after 20 minutes. Normal urination. No back pain.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why this is NOT cauda equina:
- Bilateral leg heaviness after prolonged running is normal (muscular fatigue)
- Transient foot numbness = compression neuropathy from shoes/loading, NOT saddle anesthesia
- Saddle anesthesia means numbness in the PERINEUM (groin/anus), not feet
- Normal bladder function rules out sphincter involvement
- No back pain (CES almost always presents with back pain)

Clinical picture: Exertion-related transient peripheral neuropathy.

Safe to treat. Recommend footwear change and gradual training progression.

 curved bony ridge you can feel on the side of your hip. The injury occurs when the iliac crest receives a
 direct blow, typically from a fall, tackle, or collision with an opponent.

Causes and Risk Factors: Over 95% of all hip pointer injuries are caused by direct trauma to the iliac crest. The

Treatment: The chiropractor can play a role in the subacute phase and rehabilitation
Prognosis: The prognosis for hip pointer is generally very good. Surgery is almost never necessary for isolated
 injuries. Most return to full activity within expected timeframes based on severity

How is Acute Back Pain (Lumbago) - Causes, Symptoms and Treatment diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis of acute back pain is made primarily through medical history and clinical examination.
 Imaging is usually not necessary for uncomplicated cases.

 What happens during the examination?

 
 Medical history: How and when the pain started, character and location of pain

 Functional examination: Assessment of mobility, posture, and pain-provoking
 movements

 Neurological screening: Rule out nerve involvement with radiating symptoms

 Red flag assessment: Systematic review to rule out serious underlying disease

 

 
 When is imaging appropriate?

 MRI or X-ray is rarely necessary at the first consultation. It is appropriate when serious underlying
 disease is suspected (red flags), with persistent symptoms beyond 6-8 weeks without improvement, or
 with progressive neurological deficits.

Hva er plantar fasciopati?

 

 Hvorfor fasciopati og ikke fasciitt?

 Endelsen -itt betyr betennelse, men histologiske studier viser faktisk fravar av inflammatoriske celler i vevet. Det som skjer er degenerative forandringer: nedbrytning av kollagenfibre, fortykking av fascien og redusert blodtilførsel. Derfor bruker mange fagfolk nå begrepet plantar fasciopati - en mer presis beskrivelse av hva som faktisk foregår i vevet (Riel et al., BJSM 2017).

 høyere risiko for kvinner

 hos yrkesaktive 25-65 Ør
 

 

 Tilstanden rammer først og fremst personer mellom 40-60 Ør, og 83% av tilfellene forekommer hos yrkesaktive voksne mellom 25-65 Ør (StatPearls 2024). Kvinner har 2,5 ganger høyere forekomst enn menn. Blant løpere ser man prevalens på 5-10%, og enkelte studier rapporterer opptil 22%.

Når trenger du profesjonell hjelp?

 

 Selvbehandling er effektivt for de fleste, men ikke alle. Søk profesjonell vurdering dersom:

 
 Plagene vedvarer mer enn 4-6 uker med konsekvent egenbehandling

 Smerten forverres til tross for tiltak

 Du har problemer med å tygge eller snakke normalt

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 
 Manuell behandling: Forskning viser at kombinasjonen av manuell terapi og Øvelser gir bedre resultater enn Øvelser alene. En systematisk oversikt (PMC, 2020) fant at kombinasjonsbehandling gå 6 mm storre forbedring i gapeevne.

 Vurdering av nakke og holdning: Nakkeproblemer og TMD henger ofte sammen. Behandling rettet mot både kjeve og nakke gir ofte best resultat.

 Veiledet ovelsesprogram: Individuelt tilpassede Øvelser basert på din spesifikke situasjon.
